definition: EEG background activity at 4-5/second.|EEG background activity at 4-5/second is rare and unusual but not generally pathologic.

name: Alpha-EEG
label: Alpha-EEG
definition: EEG dominated by diffuse alpha-waves (8-13Hz).|Alpha-EEG is a rare finding but not generally pathologic.

name: Beta-EEG
label: Beta-EEG
definition: EEG dominated by diffuse beta-waves (>13 Hz).|Beta-EEG is a rare finding but not generally pathologic.

name: Partial beta-EEG
label: Partial beta-EEG
definition: EEG dominated by diffuse beta waves (>13 Hz) with occipitally localized alpha waves (8-13 Hz).|A partial beta-EEG is a rare finding but not generally pathologic.

name: Low voltage EEG
label: Low voltage EEG
definition: EEG with an amplitude less than 30 microvolts without observable occipital alpha rhythm (8-13 Hz).|A low voltage EEG is a rare finding but not generally pathologic.

name: Interictal epileptiform activity
label: Interictal epileptiform activity
definition: Epileptiform activity refers to distinctive EEG waves or complexes distinguished from background activity found in in a proportion of human subjects with epilepsy, but which can also be found in subjects without seizures. Interictal epileptiform activity refers to such activity that occurs in the absence of a clinical or subclinical seizure.|Epileptiform EEG discharges include small sharp spikes (SSSs), wicket spikes, 14- and 6-Hz positive spikes, phantom spike and waves, psychomotor variant, subclinical rhythmic EEG discharges of adults (SREDA), and midline theta rhythm.

name: EEG with hyperventilation-induced focal epileptiform discharges
label: EEG with hyperventilation-induced focal epileptiform discharges
definition: Focal epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).

name: EEG with hyperventilation-induced generalized epileptiform discharges
label: EEG with hyperventilation-induced generalized epileptiform discharges
definition: Generalized epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).

name: EEG with focal epileptiform discharges
label: EEG with focal epileptiform discharges
definition: EEG discharges recorded in particular areas of a localized (focal) abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).|Note that a focal EEG abnormality is not synonymous with "focal epileptiform discharges" because a focal EEG abnormality is not necessarily epileptiform (e.g., it could be a focal slowing).

name: Focal epileptiform discharges with limited propagation to contralateral hemisphere
label: Focal epileptiform discharges with limited propagation to contralateral hemisphere
definition: Focal epileptiform discharges with spreading to contralateral hemisphere but without secondary generalization.

name: Focal EEG discharges with propagation to ipsilateral hemisphere
label: Focal EEG discharges with propagation to ipsilateral hemisphere
definition: Focal epileptiform discharges with spreading to the hemisphere on the same side of the brain.

name: Focal EEG discharges with secondary generalization
label: Focal EEG discharges with secondary generalization
definition: Focal EEG discharges that secondarily spread to both hemispheres and can then be recorded over the entire scalp.

name: Bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
label: Bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
definition: Epileptiform discharges being identified at multiple locations in both hemispheres.

name: Uni- and bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
label: Uni- and bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
definition: Epileptiform discharges identified at multiple locations temporarily in both hemispheres and temporarily in one hemisphere.

name: Unilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
label: Unilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
definition: Epileptiform discharges being identified at multiple locations in one hemisphere.

name: Polymorphic focal epileptiform discharges
label: Polymorphic focal epileptiform discharges
definition: Focal epileptiform discharges of different shapes and frequencies.

name: EEG with focal spikes
label: EEG with focal spikes
definition: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.

name: EEG with series of focal spikes
label: EEG with series of focal spikes
definition: Focal spikes occurring for several seconds.

name: EEG with focal sharp slow waves
label: EEG with focal sharp slow waves
definition: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.

name: EEG with focal sharp waves
label: EEG with focal sharp waves
definition: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

name: EEG with focal spike waves
label: EEG with focal spike waves
definition: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.

name: EEG with generalized epileptiform discharges
label: EEG with generalized epileptiform discharges
definition: EEG discharges recorded on the entire scalp typically seen in persons with epilepsy.|Spikes (<70 ms) and sharp waves (70-200 ms) are sharp transient waves that have a strong association with epilepsy. No difference is noted in terms of clinical significance of spikes and sharp waves. Significant spikes usually are followed by a slow wave.

name: EEG with generalized sharp slow waves
label: EEG with generalized sharp slow waves
definition: EEG with generalized sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.

name: EEG with generalized polymorphic epileptiform discharges
label: EEG with generalized polymorphic epileptiform discharges
definition: Generalized epileptiform discharges of different shapes and frequencies.

name: EEG with changes in voltage
label: EEG with changes in voltage
definition: EEG with abnormal amplitude.

name: EEG with diffuse acceleration
label: EEG with diffuse acceleration
definition: EEG frequency is abnormally increased.

name: EEG with abnormally slow frequencies
label: EEG with abnormally slow frequencies
definition: EEG with abnormally slow frequencies.

name: EEG with continuous slow activity
label: EEG with continuous slow activity
definition: EEG showing diffuse slowing without interruption.

name: EEG with intermittent slow activity
label: EEG with intermittent slow activity
definition: Non-continuous diffuse slowing of electroencephalographic patterns.

name: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 1
label: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 1
definition: Slowing at frequencies between 7.5 and 8.5 Hz.

name: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 2
label: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 2
definition: Generalized slowing of EEG activity at frequencies between 4-7 Hz.

name: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 3
label: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 3
definition: Generalized slowing of EEG activity at frequencies between 0.5-3 Hz.

name: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 4
label: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 4
definition: EEG without electrical activity.

name: EEG with occipital slowing
label: EEG with occipital slowing
definition: Slowing in occipital areas of the scalp EEG.

name: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade I
label: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade I
definition: Occurrence of epileptiform discharges in occipital regions during photic stimulation.

name: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade II
label: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade II
definition: Occurence of epileptiform discharges in occipital and central regions during photic stimulation.

name: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade III
label: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade III
definition: Occurrence of epileptiform discharges in occipital, central, temporal and parietal regions during photic stimulation.

name: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade IV
label: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade IV
definition: Occurrence of generalized epileptiform discharges during photic stimulation.

name: Hemihypsarrhythmia
label: Hemihypsarrhythmia
definition: Hypsarrhythmia occurring in one hemisphere.

name: Abnormal shape of the occiput
label: Abnormal shape of the occiput
definition: An abnormal shape of occiput.

name: Abnormal shape of the frontal region
label: Abnormal shape of the frontal region
definition: An abnormal shape of the frontal part of the head.

name: Short face
label: Short face
definition: Facial height (length) is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or an apparent decrease in the height (length) of the face (subjective).|Objective measurement of face height is made with sliding calipers from the nasion, just above the depth of the nasal root to the gnathion, the inferior border of the mandible, both in the midline. Note that short face is distinct from wide face.

name: Prominent forehead
label: Prominent forehead
definition: Forward prominence of the entire forehead, due to protrusion of the frontal bone.|Not to be confused with frontal bossing.

name: Vertical forehead creases
label: Vertical forehead creases
definition: Vertical soft tissue creases in the midline of the forehead, often extending from the hairline to the brow, and seen with facial expression or when the face is at rest.

name: Depressed glabella
label: Depressed glabella
definition: Posterior positioning of the glabella, i.e., of the midline forehead between the supraorbital ridges.|The glabella is the area of the forehead in the midline between the supraorbital ridges, just above the nasal root.

name: Metopic depression
label: Metopic depression
definition: Linear vertical groove in the midline of the forehead, extending from hairline to glabella.

name: Ablepharon
label: Ablepharon
definition: Absent eyelids.|In ablepharon, the globe is continuously exposed. It is arguable whether true aplasia of the eyelid exists, or whether this represents severe hypoplasia. Nevertheless, as it is difficult or impossible to make this distinction on clinical grounds, the term was felt to be useful.

name: Epiblepharon
label: Epiblepharon
definition: Redundant eyelid skin pressing the eyelashes against the cornea and/or conjunctiva.|Epiblepharon should be distinguished from entropion.

name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the eyelid
label: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the eyelid
definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the eyelid.

name: Elevated C-reactive protein level
label: Elevated C-reactive protein level
definition: An abnormal elevation of the C-reactive protein level in serum.|C-reactive protein (CRP) is produced by the liver, and increases in concentration in response to inflammation.

name: Horizontal eyebrow
label: Horizontal eyebrow
definition: An eyebrow that extends straight across the brow, without curve.

name: Broad eyebrow
label: Broad eyebrow
definition: Regional increase in the width (height) of the eyebrow.|Broadening or flaring can be medial or lateral. Flaring is used to describe a widening with a change in direction of the eyebrow hairs.

name: Laterally extended eyebrow
label: Laterally extended eyebrow
definition: An eyebrow that extends laterally beyond the orbital rim rather than turning gently downward at that location.|The degree of extension beyond the obital rim that is considered abnormal has not been established.

name: Prominent eyelashes
label: Prominent eyelashes
definition: Eyelashes that draw the attention of the viewer due to increased density and/or length and/or curl without meeting the criteria of trichomegaly.

name: Infra-orbital fold
label: Infra-orbital fold
definition: Elevated ridge(s) of skin starting well below the medial aspect of the lower lid that curves gradually upward toward and/or across the nasal bridge.|This term excludes epicanthus inversus.

name: Antihelical shelf
label: Antihelical shelf
definition: Antihelix protrusion directed more anteriorly than laterally, forming a shelf overlying the posterior concha.|In marked cases this often appears to be associated with lack of lateral protrusion of the antihelix.

name: Absent antihelix
label: Absent antihelix
definition: No discernible ridge between concha and triangular fossa and helix.|This finding is common in a protruding and cupped ear, where the superior and inferior parts of the antihelix are often absent. This is distinct from partial absence of the antihelix as may occur in, for example, underdeveloped inferior crus of the antihelix.

name: Additional crus of antihelix
label: Additional crus of antihelix
definition: Supernumerary ridge or crus of the ear arising from the antihelix.|The supernumerary crus usually emanates posteriorly from the antihelix at, or just above, the point of its bifurcation but may have a different origin. In the former case, the finding is termed Stahl ear.

name: Angulated antihelix
label: Angulated antihelix
definition: Antihelical ridge that forms an acute angle between the antitragus and its bifurcation (stem) instead of a gently curving arc.

name: Broad inferior crus of antihelix
label: Broad inferior crus of antihelix
definition: Increased width of the inferred cross-section of the inferior crus.|This finding is highly variable. The inferior crus is usually sharply folded giving a narrow profile.

name: Prominent inferior crus of antihelix
label: Prominent inferior crus of antihelix
definition: Increased protrusion of the inferior crus relative to the prominence of the antihelix stem.

name: Underdeveloped inferior crus of antihelix
label: Underdeveloped inferior crus of antihelix
definition: Decreased protrusion of the inferior crus relative to the prominence of the antihelix stem.|This finding is highly variable.

name: Prominent stem of antihelix
label: Prominent stem of antihelix
definition: Increased protrusion of the antihelical ridge, proximal to its bifurcation, relative to the prominence of the helix.|This finding is highly variable. The relative prominence is attributable to either increased volume of the cartilage and/or the acuteness of the folding angle. Interpretation of relative antihelical prominence may be difficult when the conchal anatomy is distorted, for example, with a cupped ear.

name: Serpiginous stem of antihelix
label: Serpiginous stem of antihelix
definition: Posterior curving of the antihelix from its origin at the antitragus, traveling initially almost perpendicular to the descending helix and obscuring some of the concha.

name: Underdeveloped stem of antihelix
label: Underdeveloped stem of antihelix
definition: Decreased protrusion of the antihelical ridge, proximal to its bifurcation, relative to the prominence of a normal helix.|The degree of prominence of the stem is highly variable and is attributable to the volume of the cartilage and/or the acuteness of the folding angle. Interpretation of degree of antihelical prominence may be difficult when the conchal anatomy is distorted, e.g., in cupped ear.

name: Abnormality of inferior crus of antihelix
label: Abnormality of inferior crus of antihelix
definition: An abnormality of the inferior crus of the antihelix is the lower cartilaginous ridge arising at the bifurcation of the antihelix that ends beneath the fold of the ascending helix, and separates the concha from the triangular fossa.|The inferior antihelical crus runs in an anterior and slightly superior direction, and is usually sharply defined, and appears less variable than its superior counterpart. A synonym is anterior crus of the antihelix.

name: Abnormality of stem of antihelix
label: Abnormality of stem of antihelix
definition: An abnormality of the stem of the antihelix, which is the part below the bifurcation of the antihelix into the inferior and superior crura.

name: Abnormality of superior crus of antihelix
label: Abnormality of superior crus of antihelix
definition: An abnormality of the superior crus of the antihelix is the upper cartilaginous ridge arising at the bifurcation of the antihelix that ends beneath the fold of the ascending helix, and separates the concha from the triangular fossa.|The inferior antihelical crus runs in an anterior and slightly superior direction, and is usually sharply defined, and appears less variable than its superior counterpart. A synonym is anterior crus of the antihelix.

name: Underdeveloped superior crus of antihelix
label: Underdeveloped superior crus of antihelix
definition: Decreased protrusion of the superior crus relative to the prominence of a normal antihelix stem.|This finding is highly variable. There may be an inverse relationship between the relative sizes of the superior and inferior crura, but these findings should be coded separately.

name: Prominent superior crus of antihelix
label: Prominent superior crus of antihelix
definition: Increased protrusion of the superior crus relative to the prominence of a normal antihelix stem.|This finding is highly variable. There may be an inverse relationship between the relative sizes of the superior and inferior crura, but these findings should be coded separately.

name: Everted antitragus
label: Everted antitragus
definition: Positioning of the antitragus at an angle perpendicular to the plane of the ear (oriented away from the plane of the ear).

name: Absent antitragus
label: Absent antitragus
definition: Absence of the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.|The size of the antitragus is highly variable.

name: Bifid antitragus
label: Bifid antitragus
definition: Double rather than single peak of the antitragus.

name: Underdeveloped antitragus
label: Underdeveloped antitragus
definition: Reduction in the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.

name: Cryptotia
label: Cryptotia
definition: Invagination of the superior part of the auricle under a fold of temporal skin.|There are associated anomalies of the upper antihelix and crura. The upper one-third of the auricle is primarily affected and there is an inferomedial displacement of the Helical Darwin tubercle. Two types are recognized. Type I: the antihelix and superior crus are reduced in size; type II: it is the antihelix and inferior crus that are affected.

name: Type I cryptotia
label: Type I cryptotia
definition: A type of cryptotia associated with reduction in size of the antihelix and superior crus.

name: Type II cryptotia
label: Type II cryptotia
definition: A type of cryptotia associated with reduction in size of the antihelix and inferior crus that are affected.

name: Absent crus of helix
label: Absent crus of helix
definition: Continuum between the tragus and ascending helix, without any evidence of a posterior extension (crus) towards the concha.

name: Crus of helix connected to antihelix
label: Crus of helix connected to antihelix
definition: Extension of the ridge of the crus helix across the ear and connection of the crus to the antihelix.

name: Serpiginous crus of helix
label: Serpiginous crus of helix
definition: Curving course of the crus of the helix, approaching or joining the antitragus.

name: Tragal bridge of crus of helix
label: Tragal bridge of crus of helix
definition: The anterior origin of the crus encompasses the superior margin of the tragus, the crus overrides the upper portion of the conchal cavum and ends at the antihelix.

name: Expanded terminal portion of crus of helix
label: Expanded terminal portion of crus of helix
definition: Widening, rather than tapering, of the crus at its posterior border near the antihelix.

name: Darwin notch of helix
label: Darwin notch of helix
definition: Small defect of the helical fold that lies at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix.

name: Darwin tubercle of helix
label: Darwin tubercle of helix
definition: Small expansion of the helical fold at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix.

name: Crimped helix
label: Crimped helix
definition: Linear, circumferential indentation in the convexity of the outer surface of the helix.|The crimp is usually found in the middle third of the descending helix. The helix has the appearance of having been pinched or flattened along its posterior margin. The crimp may distort the free margin of the helix.

name: Forward facing earlobe
label: Forward facing earlobe
definition: Positioning of the anterior surface of the ear lobe in a more coronal plane than the remainder of the ear.|The lobe should be viewed from the front. This feature is distinct from the situation where the entire ear is forward facing and prominent. The lobe normally lies more or less in the same plane as the remainder of the ear. This feature should be distinguished from Uplifted lobe.

name: Discontinuous ascending root of helix
label: Discontinuous ascending root of helix
definition: Interruption between the ascending helix and the crus helix, allowing the ascending helix to be attached directly to the mastoid.

name: Cleft earlobe
label: Cleft earlobe
definition: Discontinuity in the convexity of the inferior margin of the lobe.|The cleft is often more visible if the lobe is pulled forward or when seen from behind. Tears acquired from earrings should be distinguished.

name: Microtia, first degree
label: Microtia, first degree
definition: Presence of all the normal ear components and the median longitudinal length more than two standard deviations below the mean.

name: Microtia, third degree
label: Microtia, third degree
definition: Presence of some auricular structures, but none of these structures conform to recognized ear components.|This malformation is commonly associated with atresia of the external canal, but that anomaly should be coded separately. Complete absence of the ear should be coded as Anotia.

name: Absent tragus
label: Absent tragus
definition: Lack of convexity or prominence of the contour of the ridge between the bottom of the incisura and the confluence of the ascending helix and crus helix.|This appears to be unusual in an otherwise normal ear, and is most often seen in microtia with atretic auditory meatus, but those findings should be coded separately.

name: Bifid tragus
label: Bifid tragus
definition: Increased height of the tragal ridge with a shallow indentation at the apex, giving the appearance of a double peak.

name: Duplicated tragus
label: Duplicated tragus
definition: A complete or partial duplication of the tragus; expected to lie anterior to the normal tragus.|It is unclear how often, or even whether, this feature which would represent a duplication of mandibular components, occurs. More common occurrences in this region would include preauricular tags and pretragial duplications of hyoid origin.

name: Prominent tragus
label: Prominent tragus
definition: Increase posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.

name: Underdeveloped tragus
label: Underdeveloped tragus
definition: Decreased posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.

name: Anisocytosis
label: Anisocytosis
definition: Abnormally increased variability in the size of erythrocytes.

name: Recurrent mycobacterial infections
label: Recurrent mycobacterial infections
definition: Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection.|Mycobacteria represent a family of slowly growing bacteria, including M. tuberculosis, the agent of tuberculosis, M. leprae, the agent of leprosy, M. avium complex species, and others. Mycobacteria infection can be asymptomatic or not, and are typically difficult to treat with antibiotics.

name: Recurrent mycobacterium avium complex infections
label: Recurrent mycobacterium avium complex infections
definition: Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial avium complex infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection.|Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is a group of species including M. avium, M. avium paratuberculosis, and others. Disseminated MAC infections can be seen associated with HIV infection. Pulmonary disease and cervical adenitis are other sequellae of MAC infection.

name: Abnormality of the urinary system physiology
label: Abnormality of the urinary system physiology

name: Intrapulmonary sequestration
label: Intrapulmonary sequestration
definition: A type of pulmonary sequestration that occurs within the visceral pleura of normal lung tissue, usually without communication with the tracheobronchial tree.

name: Abnormality of urine bicarbonate concentration
label: Abnormality of urine bicarbonate concentration
definition: An abnormality of the concentration of hydrogencarbonate in the urine.

name: Abnormality of urine calcium concentration
label: Abnormality of urine calcium concentration
definition: An abnormality of calcium concentration in the urine.

name: Abnormality of urine catecholamine concentration
label: Abnormality of urine catecholamine concentration
definition: An abnormal level of urinary catecholamine concentration.|Any anomaly in the urinary amount of catecholamines, including adrenaline, noradrenaline and L-dopamine.

name: Abnormality of hindbrain morphology
label: Abnormality of hindbrain morphology
definition: An abnormality of the hindbrain, also known as the rhombencephalon.|The hindbrain consists of two main structures: The pons and the cerebellum.

name: Abnormality of the metencephalon
label: Abnormality of the metencephalon
definition: An abnormality of the metencephalon. The metencephalon is the part of the hindbrain that consists of the pons and the cerebellum.

name: Short-segment aganglionic megacolon
label: Short-segment aganglionic megacolon
definition: A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment does not extend beyond the upper sigmoid.

name: Long-segment aganglionic megacolon
label: Long-segment aganglionic megacolon
definition: A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment extends proximal to the sigmoid.

name: Total colonic aganglionosis
label: Total colonic aganglionosis
definition: A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment comprises the entire colon.

name: EEG with occipital sharp slow waves
label: EEG with occipital sharp slow waves
definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the occipital region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.

name: EEG with parietal sharp slow waves
label: EEG with parietal sharp slow waves
definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the parietal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.

name: EEG with temporal sharp slow waves
label: EEG with temporal sharp slow waves
definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the temporal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.

name: EEG with frontal sharp slow waves
label: EEG with frontal sharp slow waves
definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the frontal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.

name: EEG with central sharp slow waves
label: EEG with central sharp slow waves
definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the central region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.

name: EEG with occipital sharp waves
label: EEG with occipital sharp waves
definition: EEG with sharp waves in the occipital region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

name: EEG with central sharp waves
label: EEG with central sharp waves
definition: EEG with sharp waves in the central region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

name: EEG with frontal sharp waves
label: EEG with frontal sharp waves
definition: EEG with sharp waves in the frontal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

name: EEG with parietal sharp waves
label: EEG with parietal sharp waves
definition: EEG with sharp waves in the parietal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

name: EEG with temporal sharp waves
label: EEG with temporal sharp waves
definition: EEG with sharp waves in the temporal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

name: Abnormal digit morphology
label: Abnormal digit morphology
definition: A morphological abnormality of a digit, i.e., of a finger or toe.

name: Prominent digit pad
label: Prominent digit pad
definition: A soft tissue prominence of the ventral aspects of the fingertips or toe tips.|The prominence of the finger or toe pads varies throughout life, being greater in neonates and dependent on the state of hydration. This term should not be used if the digit has clubbing. Note that the synonym "fetal fingertip pads" should not be interpreted to mean that the prominent pad necessarily was present in this individual since fetal life. We do not endorse the use of the term "Persistent fetal pads" as this term implies knowledge of the natural history of this finding, which may or may not be known.

name: Partial absence of finger
label: Partial absence of finger
definition: The absence of a phalangeal segment of a finger.|The part that is absent may be specified. The "distal" modifier specifies the loss of the distal phalanx; clinically this is defined by the absence of the nail. The "proximal" modifier specifies the loss of the proximal or middle phalanx with the nail still present and/or the radiographic finding of a remaining phalanx that is similar to a distal phalanx. It may be difficult to determine which phalanx is absent without x-rays and even then, there are circumstances where the missing bone may not be exactly identified (note that no attempt is made to distinguish missing middle from proximal phalanges). In this situation the location adjective will have to be removed. This finding is distinct from Short fingers.

name: Broad fingertip
label: Broad fingertip
definition: Increased width of the distal segment of a finger.|This term should be reserved for use when the distal digit is significantly broader than the middle part. It should not be used if the digit has Clubbing or Macrodactyly or if the entire finger is broad.

name: Absent foot
label: Absent foot
definition: The total absence of the foot, with no bony elements distal to the tibia or fibula.

name: Long palm
label: Long palm
definition: For children from birth to 16 years of age the length of the palm is more than the 97th centile; or, the length of the palm appears relatively long compared to the finger length or the limb length.

name: Convex contour of sole
label: Convex contour of sole
definition: The contour of the foot in lateral profile has a convex shape.|This term was established as the convex contour may occur without the prominent heel, which together comprise the bundled term Rocker-bottom foot.

name: Broad thumb
label: Broad thumb
definition: Increased thumb width without increased dorso-ventral dimension.|Note that this term should not be used for thumbs that meet the definition for Macrodactyly.

name: Partial absence of toe
label: Partial absence of toe
definition: The absence of a phalangeal segment of a toe or hallux.|The part that is absent may be specified. The "distal" modifier specifies the loss of the distal phalanx; clinically this is defined by the absence of the nail. The "proximal" modifier specifies the loss of the proximal or middle phalanx with the nail still present. It may be difficult to know which phalanx is absent without X-rays and even then, the missing bone may not be identified (note no attempt is made to distinguish missing middle from proximal phalanges). In this situation the location adjective should be removed. Note that this finding is distinct from Short toes, (which are reduced in length but have the normal number of phalangeal segments). Partial absence of the hallux is an alternative term that may be used for the first toe.

name: Splayed toes
label: Splayed toes
definition: Divergence of digits along the anteroposterior axis (in the plane of the sole).

name: Slender toe
label: Slender toe
definition: Toes that are disproportionately narrow (reduced girth) for the hand/foot size or build of the individual.

name: Tapered toe
label: Tapered toe
definition: The gradual reduction in girth of the toe from proximal to distal.

name: Bridged palmar crease
label: Bridged palmar crease
definition: A crease that connects the proximal and distal transverse palmar creases.|The crease that connects the two transverse creases should itself be more in the transverse (antero-posterior) than longitudinal (proximo-distal) orientation.

name: Sydney crease
label: Sydney crease
definition: Extension of the proximal transverse crease (five finger crease) to the ulnar edge of the palm.|The proximal transverse (five finger) crease starts on the radial side of the hand near the base of the index finger and extends toward the ulnar side of the palm, but does not reach the ulnar side. In this finding, the crease extends completely to the ulnar margin of the palm.

name: Fused nails
label: Fused nails
definition: A nail plate that has a longitudinal separation with partially separated nails, each with a separate lateral radius of curvature.|The use of the word "fused" is not meant to imply that pathogenetically these nails were separate and merged. This is distinct from a split or cleaved nail, where the two parts of the nails share the same radius of curvature. The involved digits should be specified. It may be associated with underlying syndactylous digits, but these are coded separately.

name: Narrow nail
label: Narrow nail
definition: Decreased width of nail.

name: Abnormality of long bone morphology
label: Abnormality of long bone morphology
definition: An abnormality of size or shape of the long bones.

name: Unicoronal synostosis
label: Unicoronal synostosis
definition: Synostosis affecting only one of the coronal sutures.

name: Left unicoronal synostosis
label: Left unicoronal synostosis
definition: Synostosis affecting only the left coronal suture.

name: Right unicoronal synostosis
label: Right unicoronal synostosis
definition: Unicoronal synostosis affecting only the right coronal suture.

name: Bicoronal synostosis
label: Bicoronal synostosis
definition: Synostosis affecting the right and the left coronal suture.

name: Bilambdoid synostosis
label: Bilambdoid synostosis
definition: Premature synostosis of both lambdoid sutures.

name: Unilambdoid synostosis
label: Unilambdoid synostosis
definition: Premature synostosis of only one lambdoid suture.

name: Left unilambdoid synostosis
label: Left unilambdoid synostosis
definition: Premature synostosis of only the left lambdoid suture.

name: Right unilambdoid synostosis
label: Right unilambdoid synostosis
definition: Premature synostosis of only the right lambdoid suture.

name: Cleft of chin
label: Cleft of chin
definition: Incomplete fusion of the chin, resulting from a developmental defect and manifesting as a midline cleft or fissure of the chin.

name: Multiple suture craniosynostosis
label: Multiple suture craniosynostosis
definition: Craniosynostosis involving at least 2 cranial sutures, where the exact pattern of sutures fused has not been precisely specified.|If possible, it is preferable to annotate the precise pattern of involvement of the cranial sutures involved in craniosynostosis. This term may be chosen if more information is not available.

name: Pansynostosis
label: Pansynostosis
definition: Craniosynostosis of all calvarial sutures.

name: Anterior plagiocephaly
label: Anterior plagiocephaly
definition: Asymmetry of the anterior part of the skull.|Anterior plagiocephaly may have synostotic or non-synostotic causes.

name: Posterior plagiocephaly
label: Posterior plagiocephaly
definition: Asymmetry of the posterior part of the skull.|Anterior plagiocephaly may have synostotic or non-synostotic causes.

name: Abnormality of fontanelles
label: Abnormality of fontanelles
definition: An abnormality of the fontanelle.|The fontanelles are the regions in an infant's calvaria that are covered by a thick membrane that normally ossify in the first two years of life.

name: Abnormality of cranial sutures
label: Abnormality of cranial sutures
definition: Any anomaly of a cranial suture, that is one of the six membrane-covered openings in the incompletely ossified skull of the fetus or newborn infant.

name: Metopic synostosis
label: Metopic synostosis
definition: Premature fusion of the metopic suture.

name: Hemifacial atrophy
label: Hemifacial atrophy
definition: Unilateral atrophy of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin.

name: Hemifacial hypoplasia
label: Hemifacial hypoplasia
definition: Unilateral underdevelopment of the facial tissues, including muscles and bones.

name: Asymmetric crying face
label: Asymmetric crying face
definition: Asymmetry observed in the face of a neonate or infant whose face appears symmetric at rest and asymmetric during crying as the mouth is pulled downward on one side while not moving on the other side.|Asymmetric crying facies is caused by underdevelopment of the depressor anguli oris muscle or compression of one of the branches of the facial nerve.

name: Frontal hirsutism
label: Frontal hirsutism
definition: Excessive amount of hair growth on forehead.

name: Bitemporal forceps marks
label: Bitemporal forceps marks
definition: Bilateral temporal scarlike defects, which are said to resemble forceps marks.|Congenital, bilateral, scarlike facial lesions have been reported under several titles, such as hereditary symmetric systemic aplastic nevi, congenital ectodermal dysplasia of the face, familial focal facial dermal dysplasia, bitemporal aplasia cutis congenita, and focal facial dermal dysplasia (FFDD). The findings are congenital, bilateral scarlike facial lesions in the preauricular or cheek areas. The lesions may present as slightly depressed hypopigmented scarlike oval plaques measuring about 1 cm and may have a surrounding rim of fine lanugo-like hair. Skin biopsy can reveal an atrophic epidermis with a thinned dermis devoid of adnexal structures. Elastic fibers are absent in the affected areas, as can be shown by Verhoeff-van Giesen staining.

name: Abnormality of mouth shape
label: Abnormality of mouth shape
definition: An abnormality of the outline, configuration, or contour of the mouth.

name: Abnormality of upper lip vermillion
label: Abnormality of upper lip vermillion
definition: An abnormality of the vermilion border, the sharp demarcation between the lip (red colored) and the adjacent normal skin.

name: Incomplete cleft of the upper lip
label: Incomplete cleft of the upper lip
definition: A subtle unilateral cleft of the upper lip, which may appear as a small indentation.

name: Long upper lip
label: Long upper lip
definition: Increased width of the upper lip.

name: Mild global developmental delay
label: Mild global developmental delay
definition: A mild delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.

name: Moderate global developmental delay
label: Moderate global developmental delay
definition: A moderate delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.

name: Severe global developmental delay
label: Severe global developmental delay
definition: A severe delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.

name: Moderate expressive language delay
label: Moderate expressive language delay
definition: A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.

name: Mild expressive language delay
label: Mild expressive language delay
definition: A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.

name: Abnormality of ocular abduction
label: Abnormality of ocular abduction
definition: An abnormality involving the movement of the eye outwards.

name: Abnormality of the sixth cranial nerve
label: Abnormality of the sixth cranial nerve
definition: An abnormality of the abducens nerve.|The abducens nerve (also known as the sixth cranial nerve or cranioal nerve VI) controls the movement of the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which moves the eyeball in the outward direction (towards the side of the head).

name: Abducens palsy
label: Abducens palsy
definition: Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward.|Affected individuals may experience diplopia as well as esotropia or convergent strabismus.

name: Mild receptive language delay
label: Mild receptive language delay
definition: A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.

name: Moderate receptive language delay
label: Moderate receptive language delay
definition: A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.

name: Severe receptive language delay
label: Severe receptive language delay
definition: A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.

name: Arterial intimal fibrosis
label: Arterial intimal fibrosis
definition: Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries.

name: Generalized abnormality of skin
label: Generalized abnormality of skin
definition: An abnormality of the skin that is not localized to any one particular region.

name: Localized skin lesion
label: Localized skin lesion
definition: A lesion of the skin that is located in a specific region rather than being generalized.

name: Regional abnormality of skin
label: Regional abnormality of skin
definition: An abnormality of the skin that is restricted to a particular body region.

name: Abnormality of hair density
label: Abnormality of hair density
definition: An abnormality of the density of hair growth.

name: Generalized hypopigmentation of hair
label: Generalized hypopigmentation of hair
definition: Reduced pigmentation of hair diffusely.

name: Dry hair
label: Dry hair
definition: Hair that lacks the lustre (shine or gleam) of normal hair.

name: Acquired abnormal hair pattern
label: Acquired abnormal hair pattern
definition: An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth that is acquired during the course of life.

name: Congenital abnormal hair pattern
label: Congenital abnormal hair pattern
definition: A congenital abnormality of the distribution of hair growth.

name: Abnormal hair quantity
label: Abnormal hair quantity
definition: An abnormal amount of hair.

name: Abnormality of hair growth rate
label: Abnormality of hair growth rate
definition: Hair whose growth rate deviates from the norm.|Hair growth rate is normally about 1.25 centimeters per month.

name: White hair
label: White hair
definition: Hypopigmented hair that appears white.

name: Patchy hypopigmentation of hair
label: Patchy hypopigmentation of hair
definition: Reduced pigmentation of hair in patches.

name: Yellow nails
label: Yellow nails
definition: Yellowish discoloration of the nails.

name: Epidermal thickening
label: Epidermal thickening
definition: Thickening of the epidermal layer of the skin.

name: Mongolian blue spot
label: Mongolian blue spot
definition: Congenital deep dermal melanosis in the sacral area.

name: Recurrent cutaneous fungal infections
label: Recurrent cutaneous fungal infections
definition: Increased susceptibility to cutaneous fungal infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of cutaneous fungal infections.

name: Recurrent viral skin infections
label: Recurrent viral skin infections
definition: Increased susceptibility to viral skin infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of viral skin infections.

name: Aplasia of the inner ear
label: Aplasia of the inner ear
definition: Absence of the inner ear due to a developmental defect.|Aplasia of the inner ear is usually diagnosed on MR or CT imaging.

name: Incomplete partition of the cochlea
label: Incomplete partition of the cochlea
definition: Incomplete formation of the cochlear partition. The scala vestibuli and scala tympani separated by the cochlear partition, except in the apical turn where the two scalae are in continuity via the helicotrema.

name: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type I
label: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type I
definition: Incomplete partition I is also known as cystic cochleovestibular malformation, where the cochlea has no bony modiolus, resulting in an empty cystic cochlea. This is accompanied by a dilated cystic vestibule with developmental arrest at the fifth week of gestation.

name: Cochlear aplasia
label: Cochlear aplasia
definition: Absence of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect.

name: Morphological abnormality of the vestibule of the inner ear
label: Morphological abnormality of the vestibule of the inner ear
definition:
A morphological abnormality of the vestibule, the central part of the osseous labyrinth that is situated medial to the tympanic cavity, behind the cochlea, and in front of the semicircular canals.|The vestibular system consists of five distinct components, three semicircular canals that are sensitive to angular acceleration
and two otolith organs that are sensitive to linear acceleration.

name: Aplasia of the vestibule
label: Aplasia of the vestibule
definition: Complete absence of the vestibule of the inner ear.

name: Hypoplasia of the vestibule of the inner ear
label: Hypoplasia of the vestibule of the inner ear
definition: Underdevelopment of the vestibule of the inner ear.

name: Dilated vestibule of the inner ear
label: Dilated vestibule of the inner ear
definition: Dilatation of the vestibule of the inner ear.

name: Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal
label: Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal
definition: An abnormality of the morphology of the semicircular canal.

name: Aplasia of the semicircular canal
label: Aplasia of the semicircular canal
definition: Absence of the semicircular canal.

name: Hypoplasia of the semicircular canal
label: Hypoplasia of the semicircular canal
definition: Underdevelopment of the semicircular canal.

name: Enlarged semicircular canal
label: Enlarged semicircular canal
definition: Increased size of the semicircular canal.

name: Abnormality of the internal auditory canal
label: Abnormality of the internal auditory canal
definition: An abnormality of the Internal acoustic meatus, i.e., of the canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone through which the cranial nerve VII and cranial nerve VIII traverse.

name: Absent internal auditory canal
label: Absent internal auditory canal
definition: Aplasia of the internal auditory canal.

name: Narrow internal auditory canal
label: Narrow internal auditory canal
definition: Reduction in diameter of the internal auditory canal.

name: Enlarged vestibular aqueduct
label: Enlarged vestibular aqueduct
definition: Increased size of the vestibular aqueduct.|Enlarged vestibular aqueduct is commonly seen in Pendred syndrome.

name: Enlarged cochlear aqueduct
label: Enlarged cochlear aqueduct
definition: Increased size of the cochlear duct, i.e., of a duct that communicates between the perilymphatic space and the subarachnoid space, and transmits a vein from the cochlea to join the internal jugular.|The cochlear aqueduct surrounds the perilymphatic (periotic duct). Enlargement of the cochlear aqueduct may be seen in POU3F4 X-linked deafness with Gusher.

name: Functional abnormality of the inner ear
label: Functional abnormality of the inner ear
definition: An abnormality of the function of the inner ear.|The inner ear comprises the cochlea, three semicircular canals and the vestibule (labyrinth), and is directly responsible for hearing. Additionally, the vestibule and semicircular canals function to maintain balance or equilibrium.

name: Morphological abnormality of the inner ear
label: Morphological abnormality of the inner ear
definition: A structural anomaly of the internal part of the ear.|The inner ear contains the cochlea and the semicircular canals.

name: Morphological abnormality of the nerves of the inner ear
label: Morphological abnormality of the nerves of the inner ear

name: Aplasia of the vestibular nerve.
label: Aplasia of the vestibular nerve.
definition: Absence of the vestibular nerve|May be seen in CHARGE syndrome.

name: Hypoplasia of the vestibular nerve
label: Hypoplasia of the vestibular nerve
definition: Underdevelopment of the vestibular nerve.

name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the cochlea
label: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the cochlea
definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect.

name: Abnormality of the dorsal column of the spinal cord
label: Abnormality of the dorsal column of the spinal cord
definition: An abnormality of the dorsal columns, i.e., of the dorsal portion of the gray substance of the spinal cord. The dorsal column consists of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus and itself is part of the dorsal funiculus.|The dorsal column represents an ascending pathway mediating well-localized fine touch and conscious proprioception.

name: Central hypotonia
label: Central hypotonia
definition: Reduced muscle tone secondary to an abnormality of the central nervous system.

name: Tibialis atrophy
label: Tibialis atrophy
definition: Atrophy of the tibialis muscle.

name: Abnormal CNS myelination
label: Abnormal CNS myelination
definition: An abnormality of myelination of nerves in the central nervous system.|In the CNS, myelin is the product of oligodendrocytes (and not of Schwann cells, as in the PNS). This term refers to an abnormality of the process in which myelin sheaths are formed and maintained around neurons or the result of such an abnormality.

name: Delayed peripheral myelination
label: Delayed peripheral myelination
definition: Delayed myelination in the peripheral nervous system.

name: Demyelinating sensory neuropathy
label: Demyelinating sensory neuropathy
definition: Demyelination of peripheral sensory nerves.

name: Lethal short-trunk short stature
label: Lethal short-trunk short stature
definition: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs that is lethal at birth.

name: Infancy onset short-trunk short stature
label: Infancy onset short-trunk short stature
definition: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with onset in infancy.

name: Moderate intrauterine growth retardation
label: Moderate intrauterine growth retardation
definition: Intrauterine growth retardation that is at least 3 standard deviations (SD) below average, but not as low as 4 SD, corrected for sex and gestational age.

name: Caesarian section
label: Caesarian section
definition: Delivery of a fetus through surgical incisions made through the abdominal wall (laparotomy) and the uterine wall (hysterotomy).

name: Ventouse delivery
label: Ventouse delivery
definition: Delivery of newborn by means of a ventouse, a vacuum device used to assist the delivery of a baby when the second stage of labour has not progressed adequately.

name: Shoulder dystocia
label: Shoulder dystocia
definition: Shoulder dystocia occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts against the maternal symphysis following delivery of the vertex.|Adelivery in which additional maneuvers are required to deliver the fetus after normal gentle downward traction has failed.

name: Hydropic placenta
label: Hydropic placenta
definition: An abnormality of the placenta in which there are numerous cystic spaces within the placenta as well as placental enlargement.

name: Long umbilical cord
label: Long umbilical cord
definition: Increased length of the umbilical cord.

name: Placental abruption
label: Placental abruption
definition: Separation of the placenta from the uterus wall before delivery.

name: Age of death
label: Age of death
definition: The age group when the cessation of life happens.

name: Death in adolescence
label: Death in adolescence
definition: Death during adolescence, the period between childhood and adulthood (roughly between the ages of 10 and 19 years).

name: Abnormal blood chloride concentration
label: Abnormal blood chloride concentration
definition: An abnormality of chloride homeostasis or concentration in the body.

name: Hyperchloremia
label: Hyperchloremia
definition: An abnormally increased chloride concentration in the blood.

name: Increased serum zinc
label: Increased serum zinc
definition: An increased consentration of zinc in the blood.

name: Fetal ultrasound soft marker
label: Fetal ultrasound soft marker
definition: An finding upon obstetric ultrasound examination performed at around 16 to 20 weeks of gestation that is abnormal but not clearly identifiable as a fetal anatomic malformation or growth restriction. Such findings are known as soft markers since they are associated with increased risk for fetal aneuploidy or other disorders.|The screening ultrasound at 16 to 20 weeks should evaluate 8 markers, 5 of which (thickened nuchal fold, echogenic bowel, mild ventriculomegaly, echogenic focus in the heart, and choroid plexus cyst) are associated with an increased risk of fetal aneuploidy, and in some cases with nonchromosomal problems, while 3 (single umbilical artery, enlarged cisterna magna, and pyelectasis) are only associated with an increased risk of nonchromosomal abnormalities when seen in isolation (PMID:16100637).

name: Fetal choroid plexus cysts
label: Fetal choroid plexus cysts
definition: Fetal choroid plexus cysts (CPCs) are sonographically discrete, small cysts found in the choroid plexus within the lateral cerebral ventricles of the developing fetus at 14 to 24 weeks gestation. Imaging of the choroid plexus is performed in the transverse plane of the fetal head at the same level that the lateral cerebral ventricle is evaluated. The choroid plexus should be inspected bilaterally for the presence of cysts. The size of CPCs is not of clinical relevance (PMID:16100637).|There is agreement that ultrasound characteristics of CPC, such as bilaterality, size, number, complexity, and resolution, are not related to the risk of aneuploidy. However, cysts with diameters less than 5 mm may not be linked with trisomy and large cysts in excess of 10 mm may impart a higher risk.

name: Enlarged fetal cisterna magna
label: Enlarged fetal cisterna magna
definition: The cisterna magna is measured on a transaxial view of the fetal head angled 15 degrees caudal to the canthomeatal line. The anterior/posterior diameter is taken between the inferior/posterior surface of the vermis of the cerebellum to the inner surface of the cranium. An enlarged cisternal magna is defined by an anterior/posterior diameter of 10 mm or more (PMID:16100637).

name: Short fetal femur length
label: Short fetal femur length
definition: A short femur length is defined as either a measurement below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or a measurement that is less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The femur should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (PMID:16100637).

name: Short fetal humerus length
label: Short fetal humerus length
definition: A short humerus length is defined as a length below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or as a measurement less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The humerus should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (PMID:16100637).

name: Hypoplasia of fetal nasal bone
label: Hypoplasia of fetal nasal bone
definition: On prenatal ultrasound, the nasal bone is a thin echogenic line within the bridge of the fetal nose. The fetus is imaged facing the transducer with the fetal face strictly in the midline. The angle of insonation is 90 degrees, with the longitudinal axis of the nasal bone as the reference line. Calibres are placed at each end of the nasal bone. Absence of the nasal bone or measurements below 2.5th percentile are considered significant (PMID:16100637).

name: Fetal fifth finger clinodactyly
label: Fetal fifth finger clinodactyly
definition: Fifth finger clinodactyly is defined by a hypoplastic or absent mid-phalanx of the fifth digit. Ultrasound identification of the fetal hand must first be undertaken and then appropriate magnification accomplished. The evaluation requires stretching of the 5 fingers. The diagnosis is established when the middle phalanx of the fifth finger is markedly smaller than normal or absent, which often causes the finger to be curved inward (PMID:16100637).

name: High maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein
label: High maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein
definition: An abnormally high concentration of serum alpha-fetoprotein as compared to normal values for gestational-age.|Reduced levels of alpha-fetoprotein can be seen in some fetal disorders such as Down syndrome.

name: High maternal serum chorionic gonadotropin
label: High maternal serum chorionic gonadotropin
definition: An abnormally high concentration of maternal serum human chorionic gonadotropin as compared to normal values for gestational-age.|Reduced levels of alpha-fetoprotein can be seen in some fetal disorders such as Down syndrome.

name: Low maternal serum chorionic gonadotropin
label: Low maternal serum chorionic gonadotropin
definition: An abnormally low concentration of maternal serum human chorionic gonadotropin as compared to normal values for gestational-age.|Reduced levels of alpha-fetoprotein can be seen in some fetal disorders such as Down syndrome.

name: Low maternal serum PAPP-A
label: Low maternal serum PAPP-A
definition: An abnormally low concentration of serum PAPP-A (pregnancy associated plasma protein A), as compared to normal values for gestational-age.|Reduced levels of alpha-fetoprotein can be seen in some fetal disorders such as Down syndrome.

name: Abnormal maternal serum screening
label: Abnormal maternal serum screening
definition: An abnormally elevated or decreased level of a maternal serum marker analytes used in screening for aneuploidy.

name: Maternal autoimmune disease
label: Maternal autoimmune disease
definition: A medical history of a fetus or child born to a mother with an autoimmune disease.|Maternal autoimmune diseases with potential adverse effects for the fetus include autoimmune forms of hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism, myasthenia gravis, systemic lupus erythematodes, and autoimmune forms of thrombocytopenia.

name: Maternal teratogenic exposure
label: Maternal teratogenic exposure
definition: A medical history of exposure of the mother of a child or fetus to a teratogenic substance during pregnancy.|Commonly encountered maternal teratogens include alcohol, antiepileptic drugs, antihypertensive and antithyroid medications, aspirin, bisphosphonates, chemotherapy, monoclonal antibodies, ionizing radiation, recreational drugs, and serotonin-specific reuptake inhibitors (a class of antidepressants).

name: Anesthetic-induced rhabdomylosis
label: Anesthetic-induced rhabdomylosis
definition: Rhabdomyolysis induced by anesthesia.

name: Alcohol-induced rhabdomyolysis
label: Alcohol-induced rhabdomyolysis
definition: Rhabdomyolysis induced by intake of alcohol.

name: Abnormality of the medulla oblongata
label: Abnormality of the medulla oblongata
definition: An abnormality of the medulla oblongata, the lower half of the brainstem.|The medulla oblongata, which is often referred to simply as the medulla, comprises the medullary reticular formation, inferior olivary complex and cochlear nuclear complex, among other structures.

name: Abnormality of central motor function
label: Abnormality of central motor function
definition: An anomaly of the control or production of movement in the central nervous system.

name: Decorticate rigidity
label: Decorticate rigidity
definition: A type of rigidity in which the arms are in flexion and adduction and the legs are extended. This signifies a lesion in the cerebral white matter, internal capsules, or thalamus.|Decorticate posturing

name: Athetoid cerebral palsy
label: Athetoid cerebral palsy
definition: A type of cerebral palsy characterized by slow, involuntary muscle movement and mixed muscle tone.|Athetoid cerebral palsy is caused by damage to the basal ganglia.

name: Abnormality of higher mental function
label: Abnormality of higher mental function
definition: Cognitive, psychiatric or memory anomaly.

name: Hyposegmentation of neutrophil nuclei
label: Hyposegmentation of neutrophil nuclei
definition: Hyposegmented (hypolobulated) or bilobed neutrophil nuclei.|Hyposegmented cells are neutrophils with fewer than three nuclear lobes.

name: Ankle clonus
label: Ankle clonus
definition: Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Ankle clonus is tested by rapidly flexing the foot upward.|Ankle clonus is generally caused by corticospinal disease.

name: Knee clonus
label: Knee clonus
definition: Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Knee clonus can be tested by rapidly pushing the patella towards the toes.

name: Unusual CNS infection
label: Unusual CNS infection
definition: A type of infection of the central nervous system that can be regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection.

name: Congenital microcephaly
label: Congenital microcephaly
definition: Head circumference below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender at birth.

name: Functional abnormality of the middle ear
label: Functional abnormality of the middle ear
definition: An abnormality of the function of the middle ear.|The middle ear comprises the tympanic cavity in the temporal bone of the skull behind the eardrum, and is separated from the outer ear by the ear drum. The tympanic cavity contains the auditory ossicles (malleus, incus, stapes) that vibrate when exposed to sound, forming a chain that extends to the oval window of the inner ear and whose main function is to amplify sound. Additionally, the middle ear connects to the back of the throat and nose through the Eustachian tube.

name: Abnormality of the incus
label: Abnormality of the incus
definition: An abnormality of the incus, an ossicle in the middle ear.

name: Abnormality of the malleus
label: Abnormality of the malleus
definition: An abnormality of the malleus, an ossicle in the middle ear.

name: Absent malleus
label: Absent malleus
definition: Aplasia of the malleus.

name: Absent stapes
label: Absent stapes
definition: Aplasia of the stapes.

name: Loss of eyelashes
label: Loss of eyelashes
definition: This term refers to the loss of eyelashes that were previously present.|Common causes of loss of eyelashes include inflammation, autoimmunity, tumors,endocrine disorders, drugs and medications, and a number of congenital conditions.

name: Esophageal carcinoma
label: Esophageal carcinoma
definition: The presence of a carcinoma of the esophagus.

name: Embryonal onset
label: Embryonal onset
definition: Onset of disease at up to 8 weeks of gestation.

name: Fetal onset
label: Fetal onset
definition: Onset prior to birth but after 8 weeks of gestation.

name: Young adult onset
label: Young adult onset
definition: Onset of disease at the age of between 16 and 40 years.

name: Childhood onset
label: Childhood onset
definition: Onset of disease at the age of between 1 and 5 years.|This term refers to ages up to but not including the fifth birthday (see Juvenile onset).

name: Aganglionosis of the small intestine
label: Aganglionosis of the small intestine
definition: A lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) affecting the small intestine.

name: Duodenal aganglionosis
label: Duodenal aganglionosis
definition: A lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) affecting the duodenum.

name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the gallbladder
label: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the gallbladder
definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the gallbladder.

name: Absent gallbladder
label: Absent gallbladder
definition: A developmental defect in which the gallbladder fails to form.

name: Facial tics
label: Facial tics
definition: Sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic motor movements (spasms), involving the eyes and muscles of the face.

name: Nasal regurgitation
label: Nasal regurgitation
definition: Regurgitation of milk through the nose.

name: Nasogastric tube feeding in infancy
label: Nasogastric tube feeding in infancy
definition: Feeding problem necessitating nasogastric tube feeding.|This is a severe form of feeding problems in infancy.

name: Gastrostomy tube feeding in infancy
label: Gastrostomy tube feeding in infancy
definition: Feeding problem necessitating gastrostomy tube feeding.|This is an extremely severe form of feeding problems in infancy.

name: Abnormality of small intestinal villus morphology
label: Abnormality of small intestinal villus morphology

name: Villous atrophy
label: Villous atrophy
definition: The enteric villi are atrophic or absent.

name: Childhood onset sensorineural hearing impairment
label: Childhood onset sensorineural hearing impairment
definition: Sensorineural hearing impairment with childhood onset.

name: Persistent stapedial artery
label: Persistent stapedial artery
definition: Persistence of the stapedial artery, which normally regresses during embryonic life.

name: Profound sensorineural hearing impairment
label: Profound sensorineural hearing impairment
definition: Complete loss of hearing related to a sensorineural defect.

name: Upbeat nystagmus
label: Upbeat nystagmus
definition: In primary position, the eyes drift slowly downward and then spontaneously beat upward. Upward gaze accentuates the nystagmus. The associated oscillopsias are often very irritating, but the symptoms are usually transient.|In most cases, paramedian lesions in the medulla oblongata or the midbrain are found, for example, in patients with multiple sclerosis, brainstem ischemia or tumors, or Wernicke's encephalopathy.

name: True anophthalmia
label: True anophthalmia
definition: Absence of globe, optic nerve, chiasm and optic tracts. No evidence of ocular tissue on MRI scan or examination.|True anophthalmia implies an early failure of eye development.

name: Abnormal lacrimal punctum morphology
label: Abnormal lacrimal punctum morphology
definition: An abnormality of the lacrimal punctum, an opening on the eyelid close to the medial canthus that drains tears from the conjunctival sac into the lacrimal duct in the same eyelid.

name: Unilateral microphthalmos
label: Unilateral microphthalmos
definition: A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one eye.

name: Abnormal lacrimal duct morphology
label: Abnormal lacrimal duct morphology
definition: An abnormality of the lacrimal duct, a duct that drain tears from the conjunctiva, via the lacrimal puncta, into the lacrimal sac.

name: Abnormal lacrimal gland morphology
label: Abnormal lacrimal gland morphology
definition: Abnormality of the lacrimal gland, i.e., of the almond-shaped gland that secretes the aqueous layer of the tear film for each eye.

name: Anterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
label: Anterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
definition: Adhesions between the iris and the cornea.

name: Posterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
label: Posterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
definition: Adhesions between the iris and the lens.

name: Corneolenticular adhesion
label: Corneolenticular adhesion
definition: Developmental abnormality in which the lens and cornea are not separated.

name: Abnormality of corneal thickness
label: Abnormality of corneal thickness
definition: An abnormal anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.

name: Increased corneal thickness
label: Increased corneal thickness
definition: A increased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.

name: Abnormal corneal endothelium morphology
label: Abnormal corneal endothelium morphology
definition: Abnormality of the corneal endothelium, that is, the single layer of cells on the inner surface of the cornea.

name: Abnormal migration of corneal endothelium
label: Abnormal migration of corneal endothelium
definition: Abnormal migration of corneal endothelium.|Can be seen in posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy.

name: Abnormal Descemet membrane morphology
label: Abnormal Descemet membrane morphology
definition: Abnormality of Descemet's membrane, which is the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium.

name: Reduced number of corneal endothelial cells
label: Reduced number of corneal endothelial cells
definition: A reduction in the number of corneal endothelial cells.

name: Abnormality of corneal stroma
label: Abnormality of corneal stroma
definition: An abnormality of the stroma of cornea, also known as the substantia propria of cornea.

name: Central opacification of the cornea
label: Central opacification of the cornea
definition: Reduced transparency of the central portion of the corneal stroma.

name: Generalized opacification of the cornea
label: Generalized opacification of the cornea
definition: Generalized reduced transparency of the stroma of the cornea.

name: Abnormal corneal epithelium morphology
label: Abnormal corneal epithelium morphology
definition: Abnormality of the corneal epithelium, that is of the epithelial tissue that covers the front of the cornea.

name: Corneal neovascularization
label: Corneal neovascularization
definition: Ingrowth of new blood vessels into the cornea.|New blood vessels, which sprout from the capillaries and venules of the pericorneal plexus, may block light, compromise visual acuity, and lead to inflammation, corneal scarring, and edema. Corneal neovascularization may be a consequence of corneal hypoxia. Neovascular patterns can be separated into three clinical groups: deep neovascularization overlying Descemet's membrane (seen in herpetic and luetic interstitial keratitis), stromal neovascularization (as a result of stromal keratitis), and vascular pannus (from ocular surface disorders).

name: Iris neovascularization
label: Iris neovascularization
definition: New growth of vessels on the surface of the iris.

name: Mydriasis
label: Mydriasis
definition: Abnormal dilatation of the iris.

name: Polycoria
label: Polycoria
definition: Multiple pupils.

name: Anterior lenticonus
label: Anterior lenticonus
definition: A conical projection of the anterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.

name: Posterior lenticonus
label: Posterior lenticonus
definition: A conical projection of the posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.

name: Aplasia of the fovea
label: Aplasia of the fovea
definition: Congenital absence of the fovea.|Aplasia of the fovea can occur in aniridia and albinism.

name: Bull's eye maculopathy
label: Bull's eye maculopathy
definition: Progressive maculopathy characterized by concentric regions of hyper- and hypo-pigmentation.

name: Cystoid macular edema
label: Cystoid macular edema
definition: Cystoid macular edema (CME) is any type of macular edema that involves cyst formation.|CME can occur with Irvine-Gass syndrome and other disorders.

name: Choroidal neovascularization
label: Choroidal neovascularization
definition: Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) is the creation of new blood vessels in the choroid layer of the eye.|This is a common symptom of the degenerative maculopathy wet age-related macular degeneration.

name: Macular flecks
label: Macular flecks
definition: Pale often indistinct lesions of the macula.

name: Macular hole
label: Macular hole
definition: A macular hole is a small break in the macula, located in the center of the retina.

name: Macular hyperpigmentation
label: Macular hyperpigmentation
definition: Increased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea.

name: Drusen
label: Drusen
definition: Drusen (singular, 'druse') are tiny yellow or white accumulations of extracellular material (lipofuscin) that build up in Bruch's membrane of the eye.

name: Macular schisis
label: Macular schisis
definition: Splitting of the retina in the macular region.|This abnormality can be seen in X-linked retinoschisis.

name: Hyperpigmentation of the fundus
label: Hyperpigmentation of the fundus
definition: Increased pigmentation of the fundus

name: Retinal cavernous angioma
label: Retinal cavernous angioma
definition: A benign tumor of the retina that appears as a grouping of blood-filled saccules within the inner retinal layers or on the surface of the optic disc. Retinal cavernous angioma are described as having a 'cluster of grapes' appearance.|The lesions are variable in size and location, and frequently follow the course of a major retinal vein. Epiretinal membranes are a common feature. In contrast to retinal capillary hemangiomas, cavernous hemangiomas lack prominent feeder vessels, intraretinal exudate, and surrounding subretinal fluid. Because the fundoscopic features are characteristic, diagnosis can generally be made based upon clinical appearance.

name: Abnormality of binocular vision
label: Abnormality of binocular vision
definition: An abnormality of binocular vision, that is of the ability to synthesize the visual inputs from both eyes to a single image with perception of depth.

name: Abnormal stereopsis
label: Abnormal stereopsis
definition: Inability to make fine depth discriminations from parallax provided by the two eyes' different positions on the head.

name: Achromatopsia
label: Achromatopsia
definition: A condition where the retina contains no functional cone cells, so that in addition to the absence of color discrimination, vision in lights of normal intensity is difficult.|The end stage of cone degeneration is rod monochromacy, also called achromatopsia, in which vision is mediated exclusively by rod photoreceptors. Rod monochromacy can also be manifest from birth and can be due to congenitally absent or dysfunctional cone photoreceptors. There is no rod counterpart to cone degeneration; all rod photoreceptor degenerations have a secondary loss of cones and are categorized as retinitis pigmentosa.

name: Cone monochromacy
label: Cone monochromacy
definition: The condition of having both rods and cones, but only a single kind of cone. Affected individuals have good pattern vision in daylight, but cannot distinguish between colors.|There are three differing forms of cone monochromacy, named according to the residual functioning cone class, (1) blue cone (S-cone) monochromacy, green cone (M-cone) monochromacy, and red cone (L-cone) monochromacy.

name: Dichromacy
label: Dichromacy
definition: Individuals affected by dichromacy possess only two types of cones, instead of three.|The three types of dichromacy (protanopia, deuteranopia, and tritanopia) are named according the cone photopigment that is missing.

name: Anomalous trichromacy
label: Anomalous trichromacy
definition: Individuals with anomalous trichromacy possess three types of cones, but one of the three types of cones has an abnormal spectral sensitivity compared to normal cones.|Because the spectral sensitivities of individuals with anomalous trichromacy are shifted compared to normal, they mix the primary colors in different proportions.

name: Deuteranomaly
label: Deuteranomaly
definition: A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with abnormal M photopigment, such that the absorption spectrum is shifted toward L wavelengths. Affected individuals have difficulties distinguishing between red and green.|Note that protanomaly and deuteranomaly are both associated with difficulties distinguishing red and green.

name: Deuteranopia
label: Deuteranopia
definition: Complete lack of the M photopigment, which is replaced with the L photopigment. Affected individuals tend to confuse red and green.|Blue and red cones only; no functional green cones.

name: Protanopia
label: Protanopia
definition: Blue and green cones only; no functional red cones.

name: Iris cyst
label: Iris cyst
definition: An iris cyst is composed of a single cell layer of epithelium and is filled with fluid.

name: Iris melanoma
label: Iris melanoma
definition: Malignant tumor of melanocytes affecting the iris.

name: Iris nevus
label: Iris nevus
definition: A benign brown pigmented area over the iris representing proliferation of melanocyte cells in the stromal layer of the iris. An iris nevus can be flat or occasionally slightly elevated.

name: Abnormality of lens shape
label: Abnormality of lens shape
definition: An abnormal shape of the lens.

name: Lentiglobus
label: Lentiglobus
definition: Exaggerated curvature of the lens of the eye, producing an anterior or posterior spherical bulging.

name: Solitary congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
label: Solitary congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
definition: Sharply demarcated hyperpigmentation which is congenital found in around 3-5% of the population and of no functional significance.

name: Multiple bilateral congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
label: Multiple bilateral congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
definition: Sharply demarcated hyperpigmentation which is congenital.|Bilateral multiple CHRPE is strongly associated with familial adenomatous polyposis coli.

name: Retinal hole
label: Retinal hole
definition: A small break in the retina.|A retinal hole can be asymptomatic or can lead to the sudden appearance of many floaters or flashes, blurry, or wavy vision, or of a a dark shadow or curtain in the peripheral visual field.

name: Vitritis
label: Vitritis
definition: Inflammation of the vitreous body, characterized by the presence of inflammatory cells and protein exudate in the vitreous cavity.

name: Subretinal exudate
label: Subretinal exudate
definition: A type of retinal exudate located in the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.

name: Snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration
label: Snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration
definition: The appearance of yellow/white crystalline-like (hence the name) spots in the retina and thickening of the peripheral part of the vitreous.

name: Abnormal spatial orientation of the cardiac segments
label: Abnormal spatial orientation of the cardiac segments
definition: Abnormality of the spatial relationship of the cardiac segments to other components of the heart.

name: Abnormal atrial arrangement
label: Abnormal atrial arrangement
definition: Abnormality of the spatial relationship of the atria to other components of the heart.

name: Right atrial isomerism
label: Right atrial isomerism
definition: Right atrial isomerism is characterized by bilateral triangular, morphologically right atrial, appendages, both joining the atrial chamber along a broad front with internal terminal crest.

name: Left atrial isomerism
label: Left atrial isomerism
