definition: In left atrial isomerism there is a bilateral small finger-shaped morphologically left atrial appendage joining the atrial chamber along a narrow front without an internal terminal crest.|Left and right hand side atria have left atrial morphology.

name: Atrial situs inversus
label: Atrial situs inversus
definition: Mirror image atrial arrangement, with morphologic right atrium on the left hand side and morphologic left atrium on the right hand side.

name: Atrial situs ambiguous
label: Atrial situs ambiguous
definition: Common atrium without defining morphologic features.

name: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries
label: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries
definition: The essence of the lesion is the combination of discordant atrioventricular and ventriculo-arterial connections. Thus, the morphologically right atrium is connected to a morphologically left ventricle across the mitral valve, with the left ventricle then connected to the pulmonary trunk. The morphologically left atrium is connected to the morphologically right ventricle across the tricuspid valve, with the morphologically right ventricle connected to the aorta.

name: Criss-cross atrioventricular valves
label: Criss-cross atrioventricular valves
definition: Crossing of the inflow streams of the two ventricles, due to an apparent twisting of the heart about its long axis.

name: Criss-cross atrioventricular valves with superior-inferior ventricles
label: Criss-cross atrioventricular valves with superior-inferior ventricles
definition: Criss-cross atrioventricular valves with a rare cardiac malformation characterized by the two ventricles lying one above the other instead of side by side.

name: Superior-inferior ventricles without criss-cross atrioventricular valves
label: Superior-inferior ventricles without criss-cross atrioventricular valves

name: Abnormal connection of the cardiac segments
label: Abnormal connection of the cardiac segments
definition: A deviance in the normal connections between two cardiac segements.

name: Abnormal atrioventricular connection
label: Abnormal atrioventricular connection
definition: An abnormality of the circulatory connection between atria and ventricles.

name: Absent left sided atrioventricular connection
label: Absent left sided atrioventricular connection
definition: A defect where there is no connection between the left atrium and left ventricle.

name: Absent right sided atrioventricular connection
label: Absent right sided atrioventricular connection
definition: A defect where there is no connection between the right atrium and right ventricle.

name: Univentricular heart with absent left sided atrioventricular connection
label: Univentricular heart with absent left sided atrioventricular connection

name: Biventricular heart with straddling right sided atrioventricular valve and absent left sided atrioventricular connection
label: Biventricular heart with straddling right sided atrioventricular valve and absent left sided atrioventricular connection

name: Right sided atrium to left ventricle and absent left sided atrioventricular connection
label: Right sided atrium to left ventricle and absent left sided atrioventricular connection

name: Ambiguous atrioventricular connection
label: Ambiguous atrioventricular connection
definition: With left or right cardiac isomerism in a biventricular, the atrioventricular connections are perforce ambiguous, in that one of the connections is concordant (e.g., right-sided morphologic right atrium connected to a morphologic right ventricle) and one of the connections is discordant (e.g., left-sided morphologic right atrium connected to a morphologic left ventricle).

name: Discordant atrioventricular connection
label: Discordant atrioventricular connection
definition: Connection of the right atrium to the left ventricle and of the left atrium to the right ventricle in a biventricular heart.

name: Double inlet atrioventricular connection
label: Double inlet atrioventricular connection
definition: The condition in which both atria are joined to a single ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve.

name: Double inlet left ventricle
label: Double inlet left ventricle
definition: The condition in which both atria are joined to the left ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually there is a hypoplastic right ventricle, which may be on the opposite side of the heart as usual.

name: Double inlet right ventricle
label: Double inlet right ventricle
definition: The condition in which both atria are joined to the right ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually, the left ventricle is hypoplastic.

name: Double inlet to single ventricle of indeterminate morphology
label: Double inlet to single ventricle of indeterminate morphology
definition: The condition in which both atria are joined to a single ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. The morphology of this ventricle does not allow one to determine if it corresponds to the left or right ventricle.

name: Double inlet to single ventricle with common atrioventricular orifice
label: Double inlet to single ventricle with common atrioventricular orifice

name: Double inlet to single ventricle with two atrioventricular valves
label: Double inlet to single ventricle with two atrioventricular valves

name: Mitral atresia
label: Mitral atresia
definition: A congenital defect with failure to open of the mitral valve orifice.

name: Overriding atrioventricular valve
label: Overriding atrioventricular valve
definition: An atrioventricular valve that empties into both ventricles. The valve overrides the interventricular septum above a ventricular septum defect.|Straddling and overriding atrioventricular valves usually occur in combination.

name: Straddling atrioventricular valve
label: Straddling atrioventricular valve
definition: Anomalous insertion of the chordae tendinae or papillary muscles into the contralateral ventricle in the presence of a ventricular septum defect.|Straddling and overriding atrioventricular valves usually occur in combination.

name: Abnormal ventriculoarterial connection
label: Abnormal ventriculoarterial connection
definition: An abnormality of the circulatory connection between the ventricles and the pulmonary artery and aorta.|The cardiac malformations with abnormal ventriculo-arterial connections in situs solitus and atrio-ventricular concordance include the tetralogy of Fallot as well as different forms of double-outlet right ventricle and transposition of the great arteries.

name: Mitral valve arcade
label: Mitral valve arcade
definition: Anomalous mitral valve arcade is diagnosed based on the following features (1) An adequately sized mitral valve orifice; (2) short, thick, and poorly differentiated chordae with direct union of the papillary muscles to the anterior leaflet; (3) narrow or nearly nonexistent spaces between the abnormal chordae; and (4) greater differentiation of the chordae attached to the posterior papillary muscle.

name: Common atrium
label: Common atrium
definition: Complete absence of the interatrial septum with common atrioventricular valve and two atrioventricular connections.

name: Cor triatriatum dexter
label: Cor triatriatum dexter
definition: A congenital anomaly with partitioning of the right atrium to form a triatrial heart caused by persistence of the right valve of the sinus venosus. Typically, the right atrial partition is due to exaggerated fetal eustachian and thebesian valves, which together form an incomplete septum across the lower part of the atrium. This septum may range from a reticulum to a substantial sheet of tissue.|Cor triatriatum dexter is a Latin phrase meaning that the heart (cor) has three atria (triatriatum) whereby the 'third' atrium is on the right (dexter) side.

name: Sinus venosus atrial septal defect
label: Sinus venosus atrial septal defect
definition: An interatrial communication caused by a deficiency of the common wall between the superior vena cava (SVC) and the right-sided pulmonary veins. SVASD is commonly associated with anomalous pulmonary venous connection (APVC) of some or all of the pulmonary veins, which produces additional left-to-right shunting.

name: Double orifice mitral valve
label: Double orifice mitral valve
definition: The left atrio-ventricular connection consists of two anatomically distinct orifices separated by accessory fibrous tissue.|In about 50% of Double orifice mitral valve (DOMV) cases, valvular function is normal, others present with stenosis or regurgitation. In most cases, a larger orifice is accompanied by a small eccentric accessory orifice, and some show duplicated mitral valves. Embryologically, the lesion results from abnormal leaflet fusion and persistence of the left part of the common atrio-ventricular canal.

name: Cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet
label: Cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet
definition: Cleft in the anterior mitral valve leaflet not associated with an atrioventricular canal defect.

name: Congenital mitral stenosis
label: Congenital mitral stenosis
definition: Mitral stenosis with congenital onset.

name: Parachute mitral valve
label: Parachute mitral valve
definition: Abnormality of the mitral valve apparatus, whereby chordae attach to a single papillary muscle or hypoplastic papillary muscles.

name: Supramitral ring
label: Supramitral ring
definition: A congenital stenotic mitral valvular anomaly with a ring of tissue above the mitral valve.

name: Hypoplastic tricuspid valve
label: Hypoplastic tricuspid valve
definition: Congenital defect characterized by underdevelopment of the tricuspid valve.

name: Imperforate atrioventricular valve
label: Imperforate atrioventricular valve
definition: An atrioventricular valve that has failed to open (atretic).

name: Imperforate tricuspid valve
label: Imperforate tricuspid valve
definition: A tricuspid valve that has failed to open.|Imperforate valve is distinct from atretic valve. The hallmark of an imperforate valve is that it provides potential communication between an atrium and a ventricle. It exists as fused valve leaflets usually possessing their own hypoplastic tensor apparatus. The presence of an imperforate valve may have important surgical implications. Imperforate valve is in contrast to atretic valve with an absent atrioventricular connection. The cornerstone of the diagnosis of an imperformate valve is the identification of a thin mobile membrane between an atrium and a ventrile and the recognition of the tensor apparatus of the valve. In most cases the tensor apparatusis hypoplastic and it maynot be possible to delineate it by echocardiography.

name: Intermediate atrioventricular canal defect
label: Intermediate atrioventricular canal defect
definition: A specific combination of heart defects with a primum atrial septal defect, cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet, and inlet ventricular defect. There is one valve annulus and two valve orifices.

name: Partial atrioventricular canal defect
label: Partial atrioventricular canal defect
definition: A specific combination of heart defects including a primum atrial septal defect and cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet. There is not an inlet ventricular septal defect present. There are two valve annuluses and two valve orifices.

name: Transitional atrioventricular canal defect
label: Transitional atrioventricular canal defect
definition: A specific combination of heart defects with a primum atrial septal defect, cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet, and an inlet ventricular septal defect. There are two valve annuli and two valve orifices.

name: Unbalanced atrioventricular canal defect
label: Unbalanced atrioventricular canal defect
definition: Anatomic features of unbalanced atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) include varying amounts of ventricular hypoplasia, as well as malalignment of the atrioventricular junction. In complete AVSD, the common AV valve can be situated either equally over the right and left ventricles (balanced) or unequally over the ventricles (unbalanced).

name: Short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve
label: Short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve
definition: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve.|The chordae tendineae connect the papillary muscles to the tricuspid valve and the mitral valve in the heart.

name: Double outlet left ventricle
label: Double outlet left ventricle
definition: A congenital defect of heart development characterized by origin of both pulmonary artery and aorta from the morphological left ventricle.

name: Abdominal ectopia cordis
label: Abdominal ectopia cordis
definition: Displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and into the abdomen.

name: Cervical ectopia cordis
label: Cervical ectopia cordis
definition: A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region and without a defect of the sternum.|This type of ectopia cordis presumably represents a retention of the heart in its embryonic position in the neck.

name: Thoracocervical ectopia cordis
label: Thoracocervical ectopia cordis
definition: A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region with a defect of the superior portion of the sternum.

name: Thoracic ectopia cordis
label: Thoracic ectopia cordis
definition: Congenital malformation of the thoracic wall with partial or total displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity. This feature is associated with sternal cleft or absence of the sternum.

name: Thoracoabdominal ectopia cordis
label: Thoracoabdominal ectopia cordis
definition: Congenital malformation of the ventral wall with partial or total evisceration of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and displacement partially into the abdominal cavity.|In many cases, thoracicoabdominal ectopia cordis is characterized by partial absence or cleft of the sternum, deficiency of the anterior diaphragm, deficiency of the diaphragmatic pericardium, midline abdominal wall defect, and congenital intracardiac abnormalities. These five characteristics comprise the pentalogy of Cantrell.

name: Abnormal branching pattern of the aortic arch
label: Abnormal branching pattern of the aortic arch
definition: A deviance from the norm of the origin or course of the right brachiocephalic artery, the left common carotid artery, the left subclavian artery or the proximal vertebral arteries.|The normal aortic arch crosses the left mainstem bronchus and descends in the left paravertebral gutter. The coronary arteries arise from the aortic sinuses. The first branch of the aorta is normally the right brachiocephalic artery, then the left common carotid artery, then the left subclavian artery. Abnormal branching refers to any deviance from the norm of the origin or course of these branches or the proximal vertebral arteries. An anomaly of the aortic arch that results in complete encirclement of the trachea and oesophagus by vascular structures is a vascular ring.

name: Cervical aortic arch
label: Cervical aortic arch
definition: The aortic arch extends into the soft tissues of the neck before turning down into to become the descending aorta.

name: Common origin of the right brachiocephalic artery and left common carotid artery
label: Common origin of the right brachiocephalic artery and left common carotid artery
definition: The left common carotid artery has a common origin with the innominate artery.|Commonly the three great vessels (innominate artery, left common carotid artery, and the left subclavian artery) originate from the arch of the aorta. The second most common variant of aortic arch branching occurs when the left common carotid artery has a common origin with the innominate artery.

name: Double aortic arch
label: Double aortic arch
definition: A conenital abnormality of the aortic arch in which the two embryonic aortc arches form a vascular ring that surrounds the trachea or esophagus and then join to form the descending aorta. Double aortic arch can cause symptoms because of compression of the esophagus (dysphagia, cyanosis while eating) or trachea (stridor).

name: Left aortic arch with cervical origin of the right subclavian artery
label: Left aortic arch with cervical origin of the right subclavian artery

name: Left aortic arch with isolated subclavian artery
label: Left aortic arch with isolated subclavian artery
definition: The subclavian artery arises from ductus arteriosus. While the ductus arteriosus is patent its blood supply comes from the ductus, hence from the pulmonary artery. After it closes, the blood supply is retrogradely from the vertebral artery via the circle of Willis.

name: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
label: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
definition: A patent ductus arteriosus or ductal ligament completes the ring.

name: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
label: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
definition: Aortic arch crosses the right mainstem bronchus. The left carotid artery is the first branch, right carotid artery the second branch and right subclavian artery as the third branch.

name: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal right subclavian artery
label: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal right subclavian artery
definition: Aortic arch crosses the left mainstem bronchus. The first branch is the right carotid artery, the second branch is the left carotid artery, the third branch is the subclavian artery, the fourth branch is the right subclavian artery arising from the posteromedial aspect of the distal aortic arch and continuing posterior to the esophagus to the right hand side of the body.

name: Left aortic arch with right descending aorta and right ductus arteriosus
label: Left aortic arch with right descending aorta and right ductus arteriosus
definition: The ring may be completed by the ductal ligament.

name: Right aortic arch with left descending aorta and left ductus arteriosus
label: Right aortic arch with left descending aorta and left ductus arteriosus

name: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal left subclavian artery
label: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal left subclavian artery

name: Mesocardia
label: Mesocardia
definition: Mesocardia is an abnormal location of the heart in which the heart is in a midline position and the longitudinal axis of the heart lies in the mid-sagittal plane.

name: Abnormal direction of ventricular apex
label: Abnormal direction of ventricular apex
definition: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex. Left sided is normal.

name: Rightward direction of ventricular apex
label: Rightward direction of ventricular apex
definition: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex towards the right. Left sided is normal.

name: Midline direction of ventricular apex
label: Midline direction of ventricular apex
definition: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex in the midline. Left sided is normal.

name: Congenital malformation of the great arteries
label: Congenital malformation of the great arteries
definition: Defect or defects of the morphogenesis of the aorta and pulmonary arteries.

name: Aortopulmonary window
label: Aortopulmonary window
definition: A congenital anomaly with an abnormal connection between the aorta and the main pulmonary artery resulting in an aortopulmonary shunt.

name: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect
label: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect
definition: A congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries with a ventricular septal defect: a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart. The ventricular septal defect is centered around the most superior aspect of the ventricular septum.

name: obsolete Transposition of the great arteries with intact ventricular septum
label: obsolete Transposition of the great arteries with intact ventricular septum

name: obsolete Transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect
label: obsolete Transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect

name: Type II truncus arteriosus
label: Type II truncus arteriosus
definition: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) with each pulmonary artery arising separate from each other on the posterior or lateral aspect of the truncus.|According to the Van Praagh classification (PMID:2856609). The Van Praagh classification additionally specifies the presence (subtype A) or absence (subtype B) of a ventricular septal defect.

name: Type III truncus arteriosus
label: Type III truncus arteriosus
definition: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby one of the two pulmonary artery branched does not arise from the common pulmonary trunk, but instead from the ductus arteriosus or directly from the aorta.|According to the Van Praagh classification (PMID:2856609). The Van Praagh classification additionally specifies the presence (subtype A) or absence (subtype B) of a ventricular septal defect.

name: Type IV truncus arteriosus
label: Type IV truncus arteriosus
definition: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby the aortic arch is hypoplastic or interrupted, and a large patent ductus arteriosus is present.|According to the Van Praagh classification (PMID:2856609). The Van Praagh classification additionally specifies the presence (subtype A) or absence (subtype B) of a ventricular septal defect.

name: Interrupted aortic arch
label: Interrupted aortic arch
definition: Non-continuity of the arch of aorta with an atretic point or absent segment.

name: Interrupted aortic arch type A
label: Interrupted aortic arch type A
definition: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment at the level of the isthmus.

name: Interrupted aortic arch type B
label: Interrupted aortic arch type B
definition: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment between the left carotid and subclavian arteries.

name: Interrupted aortic arch type C
label: Interrupted aortic arch type C
definition: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment between the innominate and left carotid arteries.

name: Abnormal pulmonary situs morphology
label: Abnormal pulmonary situs morphology
definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, which is defined by characteristics such as the number of lobes per lung and the relationship of the pulmonary arteries to their bronchi.

name: Pulmonary situs inversus
label: Pulmonary situs inversus
definition: Mirror image arrangement of the mainstem bronchi with the right pulmonary artery posterior to the right upper lobe bronchus and the left pulmonary artery anterior to the left upper lobe bronchus.

name: Pulmonary situs ambiguus
label: Pulmonary situs ambiguus
definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which the morphology of both left and right lungs is the same.

name: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic right lungs
label: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic right lungs
definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which both lungs have the morphology of a right lung.

name: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic left lungs
label: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic left lungs
definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which both lungs have the morphology of a left lung.

name: Abnormality of abdominal situs
label: Abnormality of abdominal situs
definition: An abnormality of the abdominal situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the abdomen and its organs.

name: Gerbode ventricular septal defect
label: Gerbode ventricular septal defect
definition: A type of ventricular septal defect communicating directly between the left ventricle and right atrium. This is anatomically possible because the normal tricuspid valve is more apically displaced than the mitral valve.|Echocardiography may visualize a jet across a small defect between left ventricle and right atrium.

name: Inlet ventricular septal defect
label: Inlet ventricular septal defect
definition: A ventricular septal defect that involves the inlet of the right ventricular septum immediately inferior to the AV valve apparatus.|The muscular septum is a nonplanar structure that can be divided into inlet, trabecular, and infundibular components. The inlet portion is inferioposterior to the membranous septum. It begins at the level of the atrioventricular valves and ends at their chordal attachments apically.

name: Muscular ventricular septal defect
label: Muscular ventricular septal defect
definition: The trabecular septum is the largest part of the interventricular septum. It extends from the membranous septum to the apex and superiorly to the infundibular septum. A defect in the trabecular septum is called muscular VSD if the defect is completely rimmed by muscle.

name: Apical muscular ventricular septal defect
label: Apical muscular ventricular septal defect
definition: A muscular ventricular septal defect located at the apex of the heart.

name: Multiple muscular ventricular septal defects
label: Multiple muscular ventricular septal defects
definition: A type of muscular ventricular septal defect characterized by the presence of multiple small defects in the ventricular septum.

name: Scimitar anomaly
label: Scimitar anomaly
definition: Right pulmonary venous return to the inferior vena cava.

name: Aorto-ventricular tunnel
label: Aorto-ventricular tunnel
definition: Aorto-ventricular tunnel is a congenital, extracardiac channel which connects the ascending aorta above the sinutubular junction to the cavity of the left, or (less commonly) right ventricle.

name: Congenital defect of the pericardium
label: Congenital defect of the pericardium
definition: A developmental defect of the pericardium with congenital onset.

name: Total absence of the pericardium
label: Total absence of the pericardium
definition: No pericardium around the heart, occurring as a congenital defect, not the result of a surgical pericardectomy.

name: Complete diaphragmatic absence of pericardium
label: Complete diaphragmatic absence of pericardium
definition: No pericardium over the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. It is a congenital defect, not the result of a pericardectomy. Pericardium is present on other parts of the heart.

name: Complete right sided absence of pericardium
label: Complete right sided absence of pericardium
definition: No pericardium is present on the righthand side of the heart. It is a congenital absence of pericardium rather than the result of a pericardectomy.

name: Partial right sided absence of pericardium
label: Partial right sided absence of pericardium
definition: A congenital anomaly with lack of part of the pericardium on the righthand side of the heart.|A congenital anomaly and not the result of a pericardectomy.

name: Complete left sided absence of pericardium
label: Complete left sided absence of pericardium
definition: A congenital anomaly with complete lack of the pericardium on the lefthand side of the heart.|A congenital anomaly and not the result of a pericardectomy.

name: Partial left sided absence of pericardium
label: Partial left sided absence of pericardium
definition: A congenital anomaly with lack of part of the pericardium on the lefthand side of the heart.|A congenital anomaly and not the result of a pericardectomy.

name: Partial diaphragmatic absence of pericardium
label: Partial diaphragmatic absence of pericardium
definition: Lack of a part of the pericardium over the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. It is a congenital defect, not the result of a pericardectomy. Pericardium is present on other parts of the heart.

name: Abnormal coronary artery origin
label: Abnormal coronary artery origin
definition: Isolated abnormalities of the coronary artery origins. This may be in associated with other structural heart malformations but not the patterns of complex structural heart malformations which result in abnormal course of the coronary arteries.

name: Anomalous origin of coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
label: Anomalous origin of coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
definition: A coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta.

name: Anomalous origin of left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
label: Anomalous origin of left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
definition: Left main coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta, above the left cusp of the aortic valve.|In this anomaly the function of the LMCA territory often requires extensive collateral formation from the RCA, which is often dilated. In the first month of life, physiologic pulmonary hypertension tends to preserve anterograde flow within the left coronary artery, and infants are usually asymptomatic. As pulmonary pressure drops, left-to-right shunting from the higher pressure left coronary arterial system to the lower pressure pulmonary arterial system occurs, and patients become symptomatic. Imaging findings may include markedly dilated collateral arteries and coronary veins.

name: Anomalous origin of right coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
label: Anomalous origin of right coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
definition: Right coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta, above the right cusp of the aortic valve.

name: Single coronary artery origin
label: Single coronary artery origin
definition: The presence of a single coronary artery ostium from which both coronary arteries arise.

name: Coronary artery fistula
label: Coronary artery fistula
definition: A congenital malformation with abnormal connection between one of the coronary arteries and a heart chamber or another blood vessel.|Coronary artery fistulas are congenital malformations. This term does not apply to surgical fistulas.

name: Abnormal coronary sinus morphology
label: Abnormal coronary sinus morphology
definition: An abnormality of the coronary sinus, which is formed by the union of the great cardiac vein and the left marginal vein and terminates in the right atrium. The coronary sinus functions to o collect deoxygenated blood from the myocardium of the heart and drain it into the right atrium.

name: Coronary sinus atrial septal defect
label: Coronary sinus atrial septal defect
definition: An atrial septal defect characterized by a deficiency in the tissue separating the coronary sinus from the left atrium (LA). This results in partial or complete unroofing of the coronary sinus leading to a predominantly left-to-right shunt through the coronary sinus (LA to coronary sinus to right atrium [RA]). The orifice of the ostium is frequently large because of the increased flow. From the RA side, the defect is located at the level of the coronary sinus ostium and may also include some deficiency in atrial tissue around the ostium. From the LA side, the size can be variable depending on the degree of unroofing of the coronary sinus.

name: Coronary sinus diverticulum
label: Coronary sinus diverticulum
definition: A venous pouch within the left ventricular wall, with a neck opening into the coronary sinus.

name: Dilatation of the sinus of Valsalva
label: Dilatation of the sinus of Valsalva
definition: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation of one of the anatomic dilations of the ascending aorta, which occurs just above the aortic valve.|Aneurysm is considered a severe form of dilatation.

name: Juxtaductal coarctation of the aorta
label: Juxtaductal coarctation of the aorta
definition: Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the juxtaductal region of aortic arch.|Juxtaductal coarctation usually presents when the ductus arteriosus closes.

name: Postductal coarctation of the aorta
label: Postductal coarctation of the aorta
definition: Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized distal to the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the postductal region of aortic arch.|Blood flow to the aorta distal to the coarctation may be dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus, and hence closure of the ductus arteriosus can lead to serious ischemia of the affected tissues.

name: Patent ductus arteriosus after birth at term
label: Patent ductus arteriosus after birth at term
definition: Abnormal persistent patency of the ductus arteriosus in postnatal life when birth was at 37 completed weeks of gestation or greater.

name: Patent ductus arteriosus after premature birth
label: Patent ductus arteriosus after premature birth
definition: Abnormal persistent patency of the ductus arteriosus when birth was at less than 37 weeks completed gestation.

name: Bilateral ductus arteriosus
label: Bilateral ductus arteriosus
definition: The presence of both a left and a right ductus arteriosus.

name: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
label: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a subaortic ventritricular septal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that extends anterosuperiorly and are closely related to the pulmonary artery as well, are considered to be doubly committed. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

name: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
label: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a subaortic ventritricular septal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that extends anterosuperiorly and are closely related to the pulmonary artery as well, are considered to be doubly committed. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

name: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
label: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a non-committed ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a VSD that is anatomically related to, or close to, neither great vessel, being separated from both by considerable muscle, and also has a pulmonary stenosis; abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

name: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
label: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a non-committed ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a VSD that is anatomically related to, or close to, neither great vessel, being separated from both by considerable muscle, but there is not accompanying pulmonary stenosis; the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

name: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
label: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the aortic origin. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

name: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
label: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the aortic origin. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

name: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
label: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the pulmonary origin. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

name: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
label: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the pulmonary origin. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

name: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve
label: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve
definition: Features of tetralogy of Fallot with either rudimentary ridges or the complete absence of pulmonic valve tissue.

name: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
label: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
definition: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from the ascending aorta with the contralateral pulmonary artery arising from the right ventricle.|Origin of a pulmonary artery from the aorta is also known as hemitruncus. One pulmonary artery branch, usually the right, arises from the ascending aorta just above the aortic sinuses, while the main pulmonary artery and the other pulmonary branch arise in their normal position from the right ventricle.

name: Anomalous origin of left pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
label: Anomalous origin of left pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
definition: The left pulmonary artery originates from the ascending aorta in the presence of a pulmonary valve and main pulmonary artery.

name: Tricuspid atresia
label: Tricuspid atresia
definition: Failure to develop of the tricuspid valve and thus lack of the normal connection between the right atrium and the right ventricle.

name: Right ventricular cardiomyopathy
label: Right ventricular cardiomyopathy
definition: Right ventricular dysfunction (global or regional) with functional and morphological right ventricular abnormalities, with or without left ventricular disease.|This feature is most often seen in the disease arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC). ARVC is defined histologically by the presence of progressive replacement of right ventricular myocardium with adipose and fibrous tissue often confined to a triangle of dysplasia comprising the right ventricular inflow, outflow, and apex. While these pathologic abnormalities can result in functional and morphological right ventricular abnormalities, they also occur in the left ventricle, producing a DCM phenotype, or can be present in the absence of clinically detectable structural changes in either ventricle. For the purposes of this classification, ARVC is defined by the presence of right ventricular dysfunction (global or regional), with or without left ventricular disease, in the presence of histological evidence for the disease and/or electrocardiographic abnormalities in accordance with published criteria.

name: Left ventricular noncompaction cardiomyopathy
label: Left ventricular noncompaction cardiomyopathy
definition: Left ventricular non-compaction (LVNC) is characterized by prominent left ventricular trabeculae and deep inter-trabecular recesses. The myocardial wall is often thickened with a thin, compacted epicardial layer and a thickened endocardial layer. In some patients, LVNC is associated with left ventricular dilatation and systolic dysfunction, which can be transient in neonates.|Left ventricular noncompaction cardiomyopathy (LVNC), also known as spongy myocardium, is a distinct form of cardiomyopathy occurring in-utero when segments of spongy myocardium fail to transform into compact, mature musculature resulting in prominent myocardial trabeculae, deep intra-trabecular recesses, and decreased cardiac function. It has been proposed that LVNC results from arrest of the compaction process during the second month of embryological development.

name: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
label: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
definition: Transient left ventricular apical ballooning syndrome or takotsubo cardiomyopathy is characterized by transient regional systolic dysfunction involving the left ventricular apex and/or mid-ventricle in the absence of obstructive coronary disease on coronary angiography. Patients present with an abrupt onset of angina-like chest pain, and have diffuse T-wave inversion, sometimes preceded by ST-segment elevation, and mild cardiac enzyme elevation.

name: Absent right superior vena cava
label: Absent right superior vena cava
definition: Absence of the right superior vena cava (RSVC). An absent RSVC is always associated with a persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC). During normal fetal development, the left-sided anterior venous cardinal system regresses, leaving the coronary sinus (CS) and the ligament of Marshall. Failure of the closure of the left anterior cardinal vein results in PLSVC. In general, PLSVC is associated with the right superior vena cava (RSVC) and drains into the RA via a dilated CS. When developmental arrest occurs at an earlier stage, the CS is absent and the PLSVC drains into the left atrium.|The superior vena cava is formed by the left and right brachiocephalic (innominate) veins, which receive blood from the arms, head and neck.

name: Bilateral superior vena cava with bridging vein
label: Bilateral superior vena cava with bridging vein

name: Bilateral superior vena cava with no bridging vein
label: Bilateral superior vena cava with no bridging vein

name: Left superior vena cava draining directly to the left atrium
label: Left superior vena cava draining directly to the left atrium
definition: A persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC) that drains into the left atrium instead of the right atrium via the coronary sinus, resulting in a right to left sided shunt.

name: Left superior vena cava draining to coronary sinus
label: Left superior vena cava draining to coronary sinus
definition: A persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC) that drains into the right atrium via the coronary sinus. This is the case in 80-92% of cases of PLSVC and results in no hemodynamic consequence.

name: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation
label: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation
definition: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation is the result of connection failure between the right subcardinal vein and the right vitelline vein. Consequently, venous blood from the caudal part of the body reaches the heart via the azygous vein and superior vena cava.

name: Cardiac myxoma
label: Cardiac myxoma
definition: A myxoma (tumor of primitive connective tissue) of the heart. Cardiac myxomas consist of stellate to plump, cytologically bland mesenchymal cells set in a myxoid stroma. Cardiac myxomas are of endocardial origina and general project from the endocardium into a cardiac chamber.

name: Cardiac hemangioma
label: Cardiac hemangioma
definition: Abnormal proliferation of blood vessels within the cardiac cavities attached to the endocardium.

name: Cardiac teratoma
label: Cardiac teratoma
definition: A teratoma within the heart. Most commonly, these tumors are detected in the pericardial cavity attached to the pulmonary artery and aorta. The tumour size within the heart varies from 2 to 9 cm in diameter, and intrapericardial tumors as large as 15 cm have been reported. Intracardiac tumors arise from the atrial or ventricular wall as nodular masses protruding into the cardiac chambers. Cardiac and pericardial teratomas are easily detected in the fetus and neonate by two-dimensional echocardiography as heterogeneous and encapsulated cystic masses. Histologically, cardiac teratomas contain multiple immature elements including epithelium, neuroglial tissue, thyroid, pancreas, smooth and skeletal muscle, cartilage and bone.

name: Arrhythmia
label: Arrhythmia
definition: Any cardiac rhythm other than the normal sinus rhythm. Such a rhythm may be either of sinus or ectopic origin and either regular or irregular. An arrhythmia may be due to a disturbance in impulse formation or conduction or both.

name: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent subarterial conus
label: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent subarterial conus

name: Tetralogy of Fallot with atrioventricular canal defect
label: Tetralogy of Fallot with atrioventricular canal defect

name: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia and major aortopulmonary collateral arteries
label: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia and major aortopulmonary collateral arteries
definition: A type of tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia in which all pulmonary blood flow is derived from major aortopulmonary collateral arteries (MAPCA).|Major aortopulmonary collateral arteries (MACPAs) are arteries that develop to supply blood to the lungs when native pulmonary circulation is underdeveloped. That is, the blood supply to the lungs derives from the aorta rather than from the pulmonary artery.

name: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary stenosis
label: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary stenosis
definition: The commonest form of tetralogy of Fallot characterized by pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septum defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy, without pulmonary atresia, absent pulmonary valve, atrioventricular canal defect or absent subarterial conus.

name: Subarterial ventricular septal defect
label: Subarterial ventricular septal defect
definition: A ventricular septal defect that lies beneath the semilunar valve(s) in the conal or outlet septum.

name: Perimembranous ventricular septal defect
label: Perimembranous ventricular septal defect
definition: A ventricular septal defect that is confluent with and involves the membranous septum and is bordered by an atrioventricular valve, not including the type 3 VSDs.

name: Restrictive ventricular septal defect
label: Restrictive ventricular septal defect
definition: Any ventricular septal defect (VSD) that is small enough to restrict flow across it such that a pressure gradient exists between the two sides of the VSD.|This term can be used in addition to another term describing the morphology of a VSD.

name: Non-restrictive ventricular septal defect
label: Non-restrictive ventricular septal defect
definition: Any ventricular septal defect (VSD) that does not restrict flow across it sufficiently to generate a pressure gradient between the two sides of the VSD.|This term can be used in addition to another term describing the morphology of a VSD.

name: Infra-aortic superior vena cava
label: Infra-aortic superior vena cava
definition: The superior vena cava passes below the aortic arch.|The superior vena cava normally crosses superior and anterior to the aorta.

name: Abnormal coronary artery course
label: Abnormal coronary artery course
definition: An abnormal path of a coronary artery.

name: AV nodal tachycardia
label: AV nodal tachycardia
definition: A type of supraventricular tachycardia that originates in the atrioventricular node.

name: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway
label: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway
definition: Supraventricular tachycardia in which an accessory pathway connecting the atria and ventricles, apart from the AV node, participates as a necessary part of a reentrant mechanism.

name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory connection
label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory connection
definition: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway that is called concealed becasue it is not seen on the ECG during sinus rhythm.

name: Permanent junctional reciprocating tachycardia
label: Permanent junctional reciprocating tachycardia
definition: An incessant orthodromic tachycardia with anterograde conduction over the atrioventricular node and by retrograde conduction via an accessory pathway usually located in the posteroseptal region with slow and decremental conduction.

name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the left free wall
label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the left free wall

name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the right free wall
label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the right free wall

name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the septum
label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the septum

name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway
label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway

name: Cerebellar hemorrhage
label: Cerebellar hemorrhage
definition: Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the cerebellum.

name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the left free wall
label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the left free wall

name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the right free wall
label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the right free wall

name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the septum
label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the septum

name: Automatic atrial tachycardia
label: Automatic atrial tachycardia
definition: Chronic supraventricular tachycardia predominantly seen in childhood.

name: Multifocal atrial tachycardia
label: Multifocal atrial tachycardia
definition: Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a rare supraventricular arrhythmia in neonates and young infants that is characterized by multiple P waves with varying P wave morphology and is usually asymptomatic.

name: Abnormal electrophysiology of sinoatrial node origin
label: Abnormal electrophysiology of sinoatrial node origin
definition: An abnormality of the sinoatrial (SA) node in the right atrium. THe SA node acts as the pacemaker of the heart.

name: Sinus tachycardia
label: Sinus tachycardia
definition: Heart rate of greater than 100 beats per minute.

name: Sick sinus syndrome
label: Sick sinus syndrome
definition: An abnormality involving the generation of the action potential by the sinus node and is characterized by an atrial rate inappropriate for physiological requirements. Manifestations include severe sinus bradycardia, sinus pauses or arrest, sinus node exit block, chronic atrial tachyarrhythmias, alternating periods of atrial bradyarrhythmias and tachyarrhythmias, and inappropriate responses of heart rate during exercise or stress.

name: First degree atrioventricular block
label: First degree atrioventricular block
definition: Delay of conduction through the atrioventricular node, which is manifested as prolongation of the PR interval in the electrocardiogram (EKG). All atrial impulses reach the ventricles.|The conduction of the cardiac impulse through the atrioventricular node is manifested in the EKG by the PR interval, which is normally less that 200 milliseconds in adults. Normal values are age-dependent in children, but normal values are less that 160 milliseconds in young children.

name: Second degree atrioventricular block
label: Second degree atrioventricular block
definition: An intermittent atrioventricular block with failure of some atrial impulses to conduct to the ventricles, i.e., some but not all atrial impulses are conducted through the atrioventricular node and trigger ventricular contraction.

name: Mobitz I atrioventricular block
label: Mobitz I atrioventricular block
definition: Progressive PR interval prolongation with the subsequent occurrence of a single nonconducted P wave that results in a pause. The pause that follows the nonconducted impulse is less than fully compensatory (less than the sum of two normal sinus intervals).|Mobitz I atrioventricular block is associated with a normal QRS duration.

name: Mobitz II atrioventricular block
label: Mobitz II atrioventricular block
definition: A type of second degree atrioventricular (AV) block characterized by sudden failure to conduct an impulse through the AV node without a preceding change in the PR interval.|Mobitz I atrioventricular block is usually associated with a prolonged QRS duration.

name: Atrioventricular dissociation
label: Atrioventricular dissociation
definition: Atrioventricular (AV) dissociation is present if the atria and the ventricles are under the control of two separate pacemakers. AV dissociation can occur in the absence of a primary AV conduction disturbance.|Atrioventricular dissociation can develop in response to severe sinus bradycardia with AV junctional rhythm or with an enhanced lower (junctional or ventricular) pacemaker that competes with the normal sinus rhythm and exceeds it.

name: Bundle branch block
label: Bundle branch block
definition: Block of conduction of electrical impulses along the Bundle of His or along one of its bundle branches.|The Bundle of His conducts the electrical impulse from the atrioventricular node into the ventricles. THe Bundle of His divides into right and left bundle branches. A universal feature of a bundle branch block is a prolongation of the time required for depolarization of a portion of the ventricles, reflected in an abnormality of the QRS complex.

name: Left anterior fascicular block
label: Left anterior fascicular block
definition: Conduction block in the anterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His.

name: Right bundle branch block
label: Right bundle branch block
definition: A conduction block of the right branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a prolongation of the QRS complex (greater than 0.12 s) with delayed activation of the right ventricle and terminal delay on the EKG.

name: Left bundle branch block
label: Left bundle branch block
definition: A conduction block of the left branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a generalized disturbance of QRS morphology on EKG.

name: Libman-Sacks lesions
label: Libman-Sacks lesions
definition: Libman-Sacks valvular lesions are sterile fibrofibrinous vegetations that favor the left-sided heart valves and usually form on the ventricular surface of the mitral valve.|Libman-Sacks lesions are y typical manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus.

name: Trifascicular block
label: Trifascicular block
definition: Abnormal conduction in all three divisions of the intraventricular conducting tissue.

name: Junctional ectopic tachycardia
label: Junctional ectopic tachycardia
definition: Junctional ectopic tachycardia (JET) is a unique type of supraventricular arrhythmia defined by narrow QRS complex and atrioventricular (AV) dissociation or retrograde atrial conduction in a 1:1 pattern.

name: Atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia
label: Atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia
definition: Accessory pathway-related atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) involves an abnormal electrical conduction of the accessory pathway. The accessory pathway connecting impulses between the atrium and the ventricle can be seen at any site in the AV groove.

name: Abnormality of the pulmonary veins
label: Abnormality of the pulmonary veins
definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary veins.|The right superior, right inferior, left superior, and left inferior pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood to the left atrium.

name: Supracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
label: Supracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
definition: Type 1 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.

name: Cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
label: Cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
definition: Type 2 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.

name: Infracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
label: Infracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
definition: Type 3 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.

name: Mixed total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
label: Mixed total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
definition: Type 4 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.

name: Congenital malformation of the right heart
label: Congenital malformation of the right heart
definition: Defect or defects of the morphogenesis of the right heart identifiable at birth.

name: Uhl's anomaly
label: Uhl's anomaly
definition: Uhl anomaly of the right ventricle refers to the almost complete absence of right ventricular myocardium, normal tricuspid valve, and preserved septal and left ventricular myocardium.

name: Persistent fetal circulation
label: Persistent fetal circulation
definition: Systemic desaturation of a liveborn baby resulting from persistent pulmonary hypertension with a patent ductus arteriosus and patent foramen ovale, such that the circulation in postnatal life follows the fetal course.

name: Peroneal muscle weakness
label: Peroneal muscle weakness
definition: Weakness of the peroneal muscles.|THe peroneal muscles (also known as fibularis muscles) originate from the fibula. The peroneal longus and brevis muscles are located on the lateral side of the leg, while peroneal tertius is on the anterior side.

name: Elbow clonus
label: Elbow clonus
definition: Clonus at the elbow joint, i.e., an exaggerated phasic stretch reflex characterized by repetitive, rhythmic contractions at the elbow, generated by rapid passive stretch at the elbow joint.

name: Abnormality of joint mobility
label: Abnormality of joint mobility
definition: An abnormality in the range and ease of motion of joints across their normal range.

name: Abnormality of central sensory function
label: Abnormality of central sensory function
definition: An abnormality of cortical sensation. Assuming the primary sensory modalities are intact and the patient is alert and cooperative, the presence of an abnormality of sensory function usually indicates a lesion of a parietal cortex or of the thalamocortical projections to the parietal cortex.

name: Abnormality of circulating cortisol level
label: Abnormality of circulating cortisol level
definition: An abnormality of the concentration of cortisol in the blood.

name: Abnormality of adrenal morphology
label: Abnormality of adrenal morphology
definition: Any structural anomaly of the adrenal glands.

name: Abnormality of adrenal physiology
label: Abnormality of adrenal physiology
definition: A functional abnormality of the adrenal glands.

name: Central adrenal insufficiency
label: Central adrenal insufficiency
definition: A form of adrenal insufficiency related to a lack of ACTH, which leads to a decrease in the production of cortisol by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone production is not usually affected.

name: Adrenocorticotropin deficient adrenal insufficiency
label: Adrenocorticotropin deficient adrenal insufficiency
definition: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in ACTH production.

name: Primary hyperaldosteronism
label: Primary hyperaldosteronism
definition: A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by a defect within the adrenal gland.

name: Corticotropin-releasing hormone deficient adrenal insufficiency
label: Corticotropin-releasing hormone deficient adrenal insufficiency
definition: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in corticotropin-releasing hormone production.

name: Corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor defect
label: Corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor defect
definition: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in the corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor.

name: Dexamethasone-suppressible primary hyperaldosteronism
label: Dexamethasone-suppressible primary hyperaldosteronism
definition: A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone can be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone.

name: Glucocortocoid-insensitive primary hyperaldosteronism
label: Glucocortocoid-insensitive primary hyperaldosteronism
definition: A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone cannot be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone or similar glucocorticoids.

name: Secondary hyperaldosteronism
label: Secondary hyperaldosteronism
definition: A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by abnormally increased renin levels.

name: Ectopic adrenal gland
label: Ectopic adrenal gland
definition: Abnormal anatomical location of the adrenal gland.

name: Adrenal gland agenesis
label: Adrenal gland agenesis
definition: Absent development of the adrenal gland.

name: Secondary hypercortisolism
label: Secondary hypercortisolism
definition: Hypercortisolemia associated with a overproduction of ACTH (often from a tumor), leading secondarily to overproduction of cortisol.

name: Non-secretory adrenocortical adenoma
label: Non-secretory adrenocortical adenoma
definition: An hormonally inactive adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that does not secrete excessive amounts of adrenal hormones.

name: Secretory adrenocortical adenoma
label: Secretory adrenocortical adenoma
definition: An hormonally active adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that secretes excessive amounts of adrenal hormones.

name: Abnormality of the anterior pituitary
label: Abnormality of the anterior pituitary
definition: An abnormality of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.

name: Adrenocorticotropic hormone deficiency
label: Adrenocorticotropic hormone deficiency
definition: A reduced ability to secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), a hormone that stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete of glucocorticoids such as cortisol.

name: Adrenocorticotropic hormone excess
label: Adrenocorticotropic hormone excess
definition: Overproduction of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which generally leads secondarily to overproduction of cortisol by the adrenal cortex.|This term refers to increased production of ACTH. If additionally hypercorticolism is present, this should be coded separated with HP:0011744.

name: Neoplasm of the anterior pituitary
label: Neoplasm of the anterior pituitary
definition: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.

name: Abnormality of the posterior pituitary
label: Abnormality of the posterior pituitary
definition: An abnormality of the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis.

name: Neoplasm of the posterior pituitary
label: Neoplasm of the posterior pituitary
definition: The presence of a neoplasm (tumour) in the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis.

name: Posterior pituitary dysgenesis
label: Posterior pituitary dysgenesis
definition: Abnormal development of the neurohypophysis during embryonic growth and development.

name: Pituicytoma
label: Pituicytoma
definition: A solid, low grade, spindle cell, glial neoplasm of adults that originates in the neurohypophysis or infundibulum. Clinical signs and symptoms include visual disturbance, headache and features of hypopituitarism. Pituicytomas are well-circumscribed, solid masses that can measure up to several centimeters. Histologically, they show a compact architecture consisting of elongate, bipolar spindle cells arranged in interlacing fascicles or assuming a storiform pattern.

name: Ectopic posterior pituitary
label: Ectopic posterior pituitary
definition: An abnormal anatomical location of the posterior lobe of the hypophysis, also known as the neurohypophysis. The posterior pituitary is normally present in the dorsal portion of the sella turcica, but when ectopic is usually near the median eminence. This defect is likely to be due to abnormal migration during embryogenesis.

name: Posterior pituitary agenesis
label: Posterior pituitary agenesis
definition: Absence of the neurohypophysis owing to a developmental defect.

name: Posterior pituitary hypoplasia
label: Posterior pituitary hypoplasia
definition: Underdevelopment of the neurohypophysis.

name: Pituitary gonadotropic cell adenoma
label: Pituitary gonadotropic cell adenoma
definition: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces gonadotropins.

name: Pituitary growth hormone cell adenoma
label: Pituitary growth hormone cell adenoma
definition: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces growth hormone.

name: Pituitary null cell adenoma
label: Pituitary null cell adenoma
definition: A type of pituitary adenoma that is of unknown cellular origin and that lacks immunocytochemical or fine structural markers. Null cell adenomas are not associated with hormone excess.

name: Pituitary thyrotropic cell adenoma
label: Pituitary thyrotropic cell adenoma
definition: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).

name: Pituitary carcinoma
label: Pituitary carcinoma
definition: A pituitary tumor with subarachnoid, brain, or systemic metastasis. The diagnosis of a pituitary carcinoma requires evidence of metastatic disease, either outside the central nervous system (CNS) or as separate noncontiguous foci within the CNS.

name: Pituitary spindle cell oncocytoma
label: Pituitary spindle cell oncocytoma
definition: A spindled-to-epithelioid, oncocytic, nonendocrine neoplasm of the anterior hypophysis that manifests in adults and follows a benign clinical course. Pituitary spindle cell oncocytomas are firm, fibrous, and adherent to surrounding structures and are highly vascular.

name: Abnormality of the parathyroid morphology
label: Abnormality of the parathyroid morphology
definition: A structural abnormality of the parathyroid gland.

name: Abnormality of the parathyroid physiology
label: Abnormality of the parathyroid physiology
definition: A functional abnormality of the parathyroid gland.

name: Parathyroid dysgenesis
label: Parathyroid dysgenesis
definition: Abnormal embryonic development of the parathyroid gland.

name: Ectopic parathyroid
label: Ectopic parathyroid
definition: An abnormal anatomical location of the parathyroid gland.

name: Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
label: Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
definition: A type of hyperparathyroidism that occurs following kidney transplantation, which is a treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Although kidney transplantation leads to a normalization of serum calcium and parathyroid hormone in most patients. The state of persistent hypercalcemia and hyperparathyroidism is referred to as tertiary hyperparathyroidism.

name: Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism
label: Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism
definition: A type of hypoparathyroidism with circulating antiparathyroid or anti-calcium sensing receptor antibodies indicative of autoimmunity.

name: Abnormality of thyroid morphology
label: Abnormality of thyroid morphology
definition: A structural abnormality of the thyroid gland.

name: Uninodular goiter
label: Uninodular goiter
definition: Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to a singular nodule in the thyroid gland.

name: Thyroid hemiagenesis
label: Thyroid hemiagenesis
definition: Absence of a lobe of the thyroid gland related to a failure of its embryologic development.

name: Thyroid C cell hyperplasia
label: Thyroid C cell hyperplasia
definition: An abnormal growth of parafollicular (C-cells) cells.|Thyroid C cell hyperplasia usually occurs before the development of familial forms of medullary thyroid cancer and is considered a pre-cancerous condition.

name: Thyrotoxicosis with toxic single thyroid nodule
label: Thyrotoxicosis with toxic single thyroid nodule

name: Central hypothyroidism
label: Central hypothyroidism
definition: A type of hypothyroidism due to an insufficient stimulation of an otherwise normal thyroid gland. Central hypothyroidism is caused by either pituitary (secondary hypothyroidism) or hypothalamic (tertiary hypothyroidism) defects.

name: Increased circulating free T3
label: Increased circulating free T3
definition: An elevated concentration of free 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine in the blood circulation.

name: Impaired sensitivity to thyroid stimulating hormone
label: Impaired sensitivity to thyroid stimulating hormone
definition: Reduced sensitivity of thyroid follicle cells to stimulation by biologically active thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

name: Activating thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor defect
label: Activating thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor defect
definition: Gain-of-function thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) defect.

name: Inactivating thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor defect
label: Inactivating thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor defect
definition: Loss-of-function thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) defect.

name: Neoplasm by histology
label: Neoplasm by histology
definition: Neoplasm categorized according to type of histological abnormality.

name: Neoplasm by anatomical site
label: Neoplasm by anatomical site
definition: Neoplasm categorized according to the anatomical site of origin of the neoplasm.

name: Embryonal renal neoplasm
label: Embryonal renal neoplasm
definition: The presence of an embryonal neoplasm of the kidney that primarily affects children.

name: Intralobar nephroblastomatosis
label: Intralobar nephroblastomatosis
definition: Presence of persistent islands of renal blastema in the postnatal kidney, anywhere within a renal lobe (a portion of a kidney consisting of a renal pyramid and the renal cortex above it).

name: Perilobar nephroblastomatosis
label: Perilobar nephroblastomatosis
definition: Abnormally persistent foci of embryonal immature blastema located in the superficial cortical region (perilobar).

name: Papillary renal cell carcinoma type 1
label: Papillary renal cell carcinoma type 1
definition: A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma that is characterized by small cuboidal cells covering thin papillae with a single line of uniform nuclei and small nucleoli.

name: Renal oncocytoma
label: Renal oncocytoma
definition: A renal tumor originating from an oncocyte, which is an epithelial cell characterized by an excessive amount of mitochondria, resulting in an abundant acidophilic, granular cytoplasm.|Renal oncocytoma is seen in Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome (OMIM 135150).

name: Midface retrusion
label: Midface retrusion
definition: Posterior positions and/or vertical shortening of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased concavity of the face and/or reduced nasolabial angle.

name: Enlargement of parotid gland
label: Enlargement of parotid gland
definition: Increased size of the parotid gland.

name: Hamartoma of tongue
label: Hamartoma of tongue
definition: A benign (noncancerous) tumorlike malformation made up of an abnormal mixture of cells and tissues that originates in the tongue.

name: Bifid nose
label: Bifid nose
definition: Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal bridge, ridge and tip.|This is a bundled term, but as it is useful in practice it is kept here. If it is only an indentation or cleft of the nasal tip, this should be coded as Bifid nasal tip.

name: Abnormal muscle physiology
label: Abnormal muscle physiology
definition: A functional abnormality of a skeletal muscle.

name: Abnormal skeletal muscle morphology
label: Abnormal skeletal muscle morphology
definition: A structural abnormality of a skeletal muscle.

name: Type 1 muscle fiber atrophy
label: Type 1 muscle fiber atrophy
definition: Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 1 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.

name: Decreased patellar reflex
label: Decreased patellar reflex
definition: Decreased intensity of the patellar reflex (also known as the knee jerk reflex).

name: Paradoxical myotonia
label: Paradoxical myotonia
definition: A type of myotonia that worsens with repeated muscle contractions.|In classic myotonia the myotonia improves as muscles warm up, whereas in paradoxical myotonia (paramyotonia) it worsens with repeated muscle contractions.

name: Impaired two-point discrimination
label: Impaired two-point discrimination
definition: A reduced ability to distinguish tactile sensations at points that are very close to one another. This can be tested by using special calipers whose points can be set from 2mm to several centimeters apart.|A normal individual can sense about a 3 mm separation of points on the fingertips.

name: Impaired touch localization
label: Impaired touch localization
definition: A reduced ability to identify precisely the site of a touch. This test is usually carried out by asking a patient, whose eyes are closed or covered, to touch the same site with a fingertip.

name: Agraphesthesia
label: Agraphesthesia
definition: Impaired ability to recognize letters or numbers drawn by an examiner's fingertip on the patient's skin (the patients eyes are closed or covered throughout this examination).

name: Increased cerebral lipofuscin
label: Increased cerebral lipofuscin
definition: Lipofuscin (age pigment) is a brown-yellow, electron-dense, autofluorescent material that accumulates progressively over time in lysosomes of postmitotic cells, such as neurons and cardiac myocytes. This term pertains if there is an increase in the accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient.

name: Increased urinary hypoxanthine
label: Increased urinary hypoxanthine
definition: An increased level of hypoxanthine in the urine.

name: Cephalocele
label: Cephalocele
definition: A congenital defect in the skull, whereby there is a protrusion of part of the cranial contents through a congenital defect in the cranium, usually covered with skin or mucous membrane. The term encephalocele refers to a subclass of these lesions in which brain tissue protrudes through the defect.|A cephalocele is a rare birth defect that is characterized by a sac-like mass protruding through a defective opening in the skull. The sac varies in size that typically consists of herniated meninges and brain tissue (meningoencephalocele or encephalocele) or fragments of disorganized neural tissue. Alternatively, the sac may contain only the meninges (cranial meningocele) or it may include part of the ventricle filled with CSF (encephalocystocele) covered by skin (from PMID:24931720).

name: Parietal encephalocele
label: Parietal encephalocele
definition: An encephalocele located between bregma and lambda.

name: Basal encephalocele
label: Basal encephalocele
definition: Basal encephalocele is an encephalocele that occurs along the cribriform plate or through the sphenoid bone. The mass may appear in the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, epipharynx, sphenoid sinus, posterior orbit, or pterygopalatine fossa. The important distinction from other types is that no external tumor is visible except in those rare instances of herniations so large that they protrude through the mouth or nares.|The skull base is made up of the ethmoid, sphenoid, occipital, paired frontal, and paired parietal bones, and is subdivided into 3 regions: the anterior, middle, and posterior cranial fossae.

name: Submucous cleft soft palate
label: Submucous cleft soft palate
definition: A cleft of the muscular (soft) portion of the palate that is covered by mucous membrane. Soft-palate submucous clefts are characterized by a midline deficiency or lack of muscle tissue.|Often, submucous cleft palate is associated with bifid uvula, but this should be coded separately. The muscles of the soft palate may not function properly, leading to speech problems, middle ear disease, and swallowing difficulties.

name: Membranous choanal atresia
label: Membranous choanal atresia
definition: Absence of the normal opening of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture) as a result of an obstructing choanal membrane that may be thin and strandlike or thick and pluglike.

name: Abnormality of facial skeleton
label: Abnormality of facial skeleton
definition: An abnormality of one or more of the set of bones that make up the facial skeleton.|The facial skeleton comprises the mandible, maxilla, frontal bone, nasal bones, and zygoma, as well as the inferior nasal concha, the lacrimal bones, the palatine bone, and the vomer.

name: Broad chin
label: Broad chin
definition: Increased width of the midpoint of the mandible (mental protuberance) and overlying soft tissue.

name: Chin with horizontal crease
label: Chin with horizontal crease
definition: Horizontal crease or fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin, with the face at rest.

name: Chin with H-shaped crease
label: Chin with H-shaped crease
definition: H-shaped crease in the fat pad of the chin.|The H-shape must be distinguished from Vertical crease of the chin.

name: Tented philtrum
label: Tented philtrum
definition: Prominence of a triangular soft tissue area of the philtrum with the apex to the columella.|A tented philtrum may accompany a Smooth philtrum. If present this should be coded separately.

name: Philtrum with midline raphe
label: Philtrum with midline raphe
definition: Narrow ridge in the midline of the philtral groove.|The ridge may be very subtly elevated.

name: Malaligned philtral ridges
label: Malaligned philtral ridges
definition: Absence of the usual parallel position of philtral ridges.|Hajnis [1972] has described downwards convergent, downwards divergent (trapezoid or triangular), convex (ovoid), and concave philtral configurations. Any of these findings may be coded using this term.
